She looks amazing for 60, or even pretty good for 42. Edna Wallace Hopper embraced the image of "The Eternal Flapper" and toured the country in the 20s advertising her beauty products, skin care regiment and her own 1922 face lift surgery. Her actual age was always a bit of a mystery. Rather than, as the stereotype would go, adjusting her age down, she is widely suspected to have adjusted her age upward to make her products and regimen seem more effective. According to the Ellis Island records she claimed to be 60 when she landed on the Homeric in 1925. But when she applied for a passport ten years earlier she claimed to be 32. [https://www.flickr.com/photos/puzzlemaster/9733118307] vintagepowderroom.com/?tag=edna-wallace-hopper

New Britain Herald. June 05, 1925, Second Section, Image 20 chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn82014519/1925-06-05/ed-... has a picture of Edna that complicates the situation. The woman appears to be in a top that could be the same as in this picture. The caption is "Miss Edna W. Hopper (above), dancer, god-daughter of Edna Wallace Hopper, fifty-year-old flapper, arrived in New York on the Paris with toy dog which she has dubbed Bingo." As an aside, the stuffed toy dog in the newspaper photo looks somewhat like the dog seen with Florence Walton in:

The Bozeman Courier., September 02, 1925, page 1, photo in upper right chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn86075113/1925-09-02/ed-... "EDNA WALLACE HOPPER ON WAY TO VIENNA FOR STUDY Edna Wallace Hopper, America's best known "flapper" is on her way. to Vienna to investigate the latest discovery of Prof. Steinach, who by an injection of a serum, claims to have Monkey Glands backed off the boards when it comes to renewing youth. Miss Hopper may justly claim to be an expert in regaining youth or retaining youth, for she is a woman of 62 years of age, who looks and acts like a girl in her early twenties. Daring the trip to Europe on the S. S. Homeric, Miss Hopper played ring tennis frequently and also patronized the ship's gym every day, the electric horse being her favorite exercise."

Corporal Joseph Pierce served the Union Army during some of the most significant battles of the Civil War, including the Battle of Antietam and the Battle of Gettysburg. Pierce was promoted to Corporal following the Battle of Gettysburg, making him one of the highest ranked Chinese American soldiers in the Union Army. 

Pierce injured his back badly after falling over a fence during the Battle of Antietam and was hospitalized for over a month. Pierce’s injury plagued him for the rest of his life, resulting in muscle weakness and constant pain. Despite his disability, Pierce’s pension was not high enough to support his family and he worked until his death in 1916. 

Today, Pierce’s portrait hangs in the Gettysburg Museum, a tribute to the Asian and Pacific Islander soldiers who served during the Civil War.

This is George Fried, captain of the S.S. Roosevelt. The negative has the date January 29, 1926. On Sunday, January 24, 1926, in stormy weather, the British steamship Antinoe sent out as SOS picked up by the United States SS Roosevelt. Roosevelt proceeded to the spot given in the SOS, but found the Antinoe was 100 miles off course. Using a radio compass, the Roosevelt was able to proceed to the correct spot of the Antinoe. Captain Fried kept his ship by for more than three days and succeeded in rescuing more than 20 members of the Antinoe crew, although two crew members of the S.S. Roosevelt were lost during the rescue when they were swept overboard. "Capt. Fried of S.S. "Roosevelt," Hero in rescue of 20 on freighter" The Washington times. [volume] (Washington [D.C.]), 01 Feb. 1926. Chronicling America: Historic American Newspapers. Lib. of Congress. (chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn84026749/1926-02-01/ed-...) "The Tale of the S.S. Antinoe" by John Hahn (www.sfmx.org/wp-content/uploads/2017/09/Memories-of-Rescu...)

www.wikidata.org/wiki/Q121094604 It looks like she migrated to Normanna Township, Cass, North Dakota and married William Otto Perhus. He was 15 years older than her. Gunhild is buried in the local cemetery: www.findagrave.com/memorial/110934173/gunhild-perhus Gunhild wrote a short biography of her family: "Wilhelm (Willie) Perhus was born Aug. 20, 1889. He was the son of Ole 0. and Anne Perhus. He married Gunhild Fekene May 6, 1929. Gunhild came from Hemsedal, Norway, on August 11, 1925, and stayed at the home of her aunt in Minot, for one year before coming to the Kindred area in 1926. After their marriage they took a honeymoon trip to her native land for six weeks. A trip such as this was quite uncommon in those days. Willie, never having been on sea, acted like a veteran sailor. Gunhild, however, having crossed the water once before, spent the voyage down in their cabin seasick. They lived on the original family farm where they raised three daughters and five sons. Wilma, born August 22, 1930 married Robert Foley of Denver, Colo., and now living in Corvallis, Oregon, where her husband is a counselor for the Corvallis school system. They have two children. Susan and Ronald. Maylo, born December 8, 1931, married Robert Kaiser of Baltimore, Maryland and lives in Huntsville. Alabama, where he is credit manager for Henderson Bank. They have one daughter, Tracey. The oldest son, Orton, born August 4, 1933, farms the family farm and resides there. Howard, born April 9, 1936, is employed in Fargo. Allen, born August 6, 1940, married Susan Williams of Spokane, Washington, and they are living in Portland, Oregon. Sydney, born April 17, 1942, works as a printer in Minneapolis. William, born November 27, 1944, lives on the home farm. Mary, born May 6, 1948, married Harris Whitt of Charlotte, Nebraska, where he is employed by United Parcel Service. Wilhelm (Willie) Perhus died March 2, 1969." (Source: Gunhild Fekene in Rural Cass County, The Land and People, published in 1976)

Excellent detective work, I agree with your find. I created an entry for him at Wikidata: Joseph Patrick Higgins (1889-1961) www.wikidata.org/wiki/Q122680736 I created an entry for him at Familysearch and found him in the 1940 census where he lists his occupation as "phonograph recording". The details in the Billboard biography and my guess that he was born circa 1890 helped find him. It turns out he was born in 1889 according to the WWI draft registration. His obituary is also in Billboard: books.google.com/books?id=aCAEAAAAMBAJ&pg=PA3 You really should go back to posting 50 new images each week from the Bain collection. The number of serious researchers working on the project has dwindled from a dozen to about three now, because the postings are so infrequent. The images of roadside attractions and themed entries like shoes and dogs, do not need any research.

An impounded bootlegger. From the August 19, 1925 Alaska Daily Empire:
The honeymoon of Mr. and Mrs. Fink was interrupted when the house-boat Stroller, belonging to Mr. Goddard, was held up by a Coast Guard cutter and searched for liquor. Mr. and Mis. Goddard were hosts for the bride and groom aboard the house-boat. The members of the party were released on their own recognizances. Mr. Goddard paid a fine of $500 for the transportation of liquor and charges against other members of the party were dismissed. The house-boat was released when Mr. Goddard gave a bond of $6,000. The threatened confiscation of the house bout will be contested.
To the left is the bow of CG-164. CG-164 was a 75' patrol boat (aka a "six bitter") designed and built to pursue the rum runners. 200+ six bitters were commissioned between October 1924 and July 1925. In the background is Castle Garden (during its NY Aquarium phase. That locates this photo at the Coast Guard pier next to the Staten Island Ferry terminal [https://www.flickr.com/photos/morton1905/38938961954/]

On 5th Street, Columbus, MS 2018 Streetview Item 23 from www.columbusmainstreet.com/wp-content/uploads/2021/06/Wal... "This bank building was designed and built in 1903 by John Stinson, owner/operator of Columbus Marble Works, and is noted for its significant architecture. In 1932, Machine Gun Kelley robbed a bank in Tupelo. Out of fear of a robbery in Columbus, Capt Sam Kaye was asked to loan a German machine gun he had brought home after WWI to the bank. It was placed on the bank’s mezzanine pointing down aimed at the front entrance. The bank hired WWI veteran, John Perry, to stand guard with the gun. Later the gun was returned to Kaye but Perry remained as a bank guard armed with a shotgun. The structure continued to serve as the main office until 1972 when growth of banking operations forced its relocation to a larger facility. In 1981, as a gesture of community goodwill and to honor an exceptional employee, the Merchants and Farmers Bank gave the building to the City of Columbus through the Columbus Civic Arts Council to be used as a Visual Arts Museum. When the Museum was relocated to Mississippi University for Women, the City returned the ownership."

Artist Frederick Opper created this self-portrait by hiding his face and relying on his signature for recognition as a political cartoonist in the late 1800s. In the Library collections, you can also find his comic strip, Happy Hooligan, which ran from 1900-1932.

The Puck Buildings is 295 Lafayette St and was the home of the humor magazine Puck from 1887 until it ceased publication in 1918. Opper was one of many cartoonists whose work was published in the magazine. For some his work held by LoC, see www.loc.gov/pictures/search/?q=Opper%2C+Frederick+Burr&am...

Justin Dart Jr., seen here, was an activist and leader of the disability rights movement. In 1989, Dart was on Capitol Hill encouraging Congressional members to develop and pass the Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA).

The ADA was signed into law on July 26, 1990 by President George H.W. Bush.

In the 1890s, bicycle use began to see a decline, prompting E.C. Stearns & Co. to look at a new way to promote its bikes. In a true man vs. machine, the "Yellow Fellows" bike with six riders went up against the Empire State Express train. There were a few different attempts and on July 28, man/bike prevails. At a speed of 45 mph, the sextuplet cyclists won the half-mile race.

Syracuse, Stearns, Coronado, Santa Monica, and the Big Sextuplets centerlinerule.blogspot.com/2017/11/syracuse-stearns-coro... is a 2017 blog piece that describes the sextuplet bicycle and explains that it was intended for training racing cyclists. It includes a newspaper picture based on this image (or a very similar one). Newspaper articles about the races include: * The Roanoke Daily Times., August 22, 1896, Page 6, Column 1 chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn95079481/1896-08-22/ed-... * The Scranton Tribune. [volume], August 01, 1896, Page 8, column 5 chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn84026355/1896-08-01/ed-... * The Hawaiian star. [volume], August 29, 1896, Page 1, Column 1 chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn82015415/1896-08-29/ed-... * The Indianapolis Journal. July 27, 1896, page 1, column 2 chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn82015679/1896-07-27/ed-... * New York Times, Jan 21, 1896, page 7, columns 2 & 3 www.newspapers.com/article/the-new-york-times-stearns-sex... is about new cycles at a industry show, including sextuplets.
cnymod.blogspot.com/2019/12/arthur-p-yates-forgotten-rail... indicates that the photographer was Arthur P. Yates and has other photos of the train.
Regardless of the actual history, this is a remarkable image.
Good lord that looks dangerous.
I do not believe they would be riding that bicycle on dirt. don't doubt that the event happened, and the cyclists won (doubt from a standing start), but this is a staged shot.

An article in the On the St. Lawrence and Clayton Independent., July 31, 1896, Page 1, column 3, nyshistoricnewspapers.org/lccn/sn87070153/1896-07-31/ed-1... provides a description of where the race took place "Syracuse, July 29. -- When the westward bound Empire State express was about two miles west of Syracuse, a novel race took place. Between tracks Nos. 3 and 4 six athletic young men on a Stearns sextuplet were kicking the pedals for all they were worth. Arrangements for the race were quietly completed several days ago. At this point is a stretch of cinder path about four feet wide and a mile and a half long. As soon as the Empire hove in sight, after leaving here, the sextuplet got under way. The Empire was soon abreast and the race began. For a quarter of a mile it was an even thing. At the end of a half mile the sex-tuplet was four lengths ahead. The sex-tuplet was then obliged to slow down, owing to a short bridge a quarter of a mile ahead. A number of railroad officers and bicycle men witnessed the race. Arthur Yates, official photographer of the New York Central, took four photographs of the race."
Not "the Stearns sextuplets", but "the Stearns Sextuplet". That was the name of the six-rider bicycle. en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Stearns-bicycle_1896-0616.jpg

William James "Fingy" Conners (1857-1929) of Buffalo NY (LOC note misspelling) Alternately known as Buffalo's forgotten tycoon or Buffalo's forgotten villain. Fingy was a dockworker, saloonkeeper, labor boss, newspaper publisher, financier, veteran, gangster, philanthropist and probably a few other things as well. Note he has no thumb on his left hand. There are many stories of how he lost his thumb and gained his nickname but my favorite is the one where it happened while working on the docks. Rather than crying out in pain, he announced (in a deep bass voice) "you've cut off me fingy." en.wikipedia.org/wiki/William_J._Conners NYPL has another photo of Fingy on the Leviathan that another flickr user has posted [https://www.flickr.com/photos/19321328@N05/8227820835/]

Alfred Waud was one of only two artists present at the Battle of Gettysburg (July 1-3, 1863). His rough sketches from the Civil War depicted the immediacy of battle scenes and captured motion in a way photography could not do at the time.

Many of his sketches were "translated" into engravings and published in Harper's Weekly.

June 21 marks Stereoscopy Day, which celebrates stereoscopic 3-D photography. 

Two subtly different photographs or photomechanical prints are paired to produce the illusion of a single three-dimensional image in a special viewer. The Library boasts thousands of stereographs dating between the 1850s and 1940s, which you can experience in 3-D using an original viewfinder (called a stereoscope) while visiting the Prints & Photographs Reading Room.

Daily Kennebec journal. August 24, 1925, page 12, column 1, with photo of Augustus O. Thomas chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn82014248/1925-08-24/ed-... says, "The delegation from the United States consisted of 521 Americans many of them being business men and was headed by W. E. Bradford is someone we have seen in the Bain stream, en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mary_C._C._Bradford "Mary Carroll Craig Bradford (August 10, 1856 – January 15, 1938) of Colorado was the first female delegate at the 1908 Democratic National Convention." I don't see her as an obvious member of this group unless she has put on weight since the earlier (1908 or earlier) photo and is at extreme left. A dissertation by Heather Kleinpeter Caldwell entitled "Mary Carroll Craig Bradford: Providing Opportunities to Colorado's Women and Children through Suffrage and Education" oaktrust.library.tamu.edu/bitstream/handle/1969.1/ETD-TAM... or repository.tamu.edu/bitstream/handle/1969.1/ETD-TAMU-2009... has a copy of the Bain portrait and another later portrait on page 190. From the later portrait, another possibility is that she is the woman in the center without a hat.

Charl Williams is Charl O. Williams of George Washington University in Washington, DC. This led me to (a) folders of photographs of NEA officers at: searcharchives.library.gwu.edu/repositories/2/top_contain... but they don't appear to have been digitized. and (b) searcharchives.library.gwu.edu/agents/people/1432 Her full name is Charl Ormond Williams according to link.springer.com/chapter/10.1007/978-1-137-05475-3_13 According to tennesseeencyclopedia.net/entries/charl-ormond-williams/ her papers are held by LoC. I found a 1947 photo at www.au.org/about-au/history/ but can't match it to any of the women in this 1925 photo. She would be younger than most of them. The shape of chin is compatible with the women in the center without a hat, but the face is slimmer. commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:Charl_Ormond_Williams_192... has the same chin. The Richmond Palladium and Sun-Telegram. December 30, 1921, page 1, column 4, top chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn86058226/1921-12-30/ed-... has a portrait, with hat, but without glasses. Another photo, undated, is at womenofachievement.org/heritage/charl-ormond-williams/

Cora Wilson Stewart. en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cora_Wilson_Stewart " Cora Wilson Stewart (January 17, 1875 – December 2, 1958) was an American progressive era social reformer and educator who is well known for her work to eliminate adult illiteracy. Stewart opened Moonlight School, first in Rowan County, Kentucky and then across the United States, to educate illiterate adults at night in the schools where children studied during the day." en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nicholas_Longworth "Nicholas Longworth III (November 5, 1869 – April 9, 1931) was an American lawyer and politician who became Speaker of the United States House of Representatives. A Republican, he was elected to the Ohio Senate, where he initiated the successful Longworth Act of 1902, regulating the issuance of municipal bonds. As congressman for Ohio's 1st congressional district, he soon became a popular social figure of Washington, and married President Theodore Roosevelt's daughter Alice Lee Roosevelt. Their relationship became strained when he opposed her father in the Republican Party split of 1912. Longworth became Majority Leader of the House in 1923, and Speaker from 1925 to 1931. In this post, he exercised powerful leadership, tempered by charm and tact."

He came from France on the steamship Paris on July 14, 1925, s. Evening star. [volume], July 15, 1925, Page 10, col. 3 chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn83045462/1925-07-15/ed-... Vincent Lopez (1895-1975) was an American Bandleader and pianist (dixieland and ragtime, mainly) with a weekly radio show on WJZ. en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Vincent_Lopez Billy Hamilton was a well known clarinetist in the 20s. In the early 20s the two played together in Lopez and Hamilton’s Kings of Harmony. By 1925 the band had grown in size and was renamed Vincent Lopez and His Orchestra though Hamilton was still featured on clarinet Dave Danziger is likely violinist J. David Danziger. In Summer 1925 the Vincent Lopez orchestra left from New York on the Leviathan for a 2 month gig in London playing at the Piccadilly Hotel and the Kit-Kat Club. Their departure from NYC reads like a slapstick movie scene
Lopez was tipped off in advance that some of his creditors might be intending to seize the band instruments. These were therefore hastily re-packed into crates labelled “Gear Machinery”, “China -Handle With Care” and “Typewriters -This Side Up”! Lopez himself boarded the ship at 5.OOam on the morning of departure, and took good care not to emerge from Billy Hamilton’s cabin and take up his own until the three mile limit had been passed.
The band's violinist for this trip was not Danziger but none other than Xavier Cugat. Danziger was on the SS Paris with the others on their return from London. Danziger had his own show on WJZ for a while and they certainly knew each other.

The Lopez Orchestra trip to England is described at: www.mgthomas.co.uk/dancebands/american%20visitors/pages/v... which says, "The band and Lopez left New York on 1st. May, 1925, aboard the “Leviathan”." and "the band sailed for New York on the S. S. “Paris” on the 8th July, 1925. (According to his book, Lopez sailed with the band, but the “Sailings” column in Variety for 8th July shows Vincent Lopez and band as being aboard the “Paris”, whilst there is another entry for 4th July showing Lopez alone as sailing on the “Berengaria”. Maybe his original intention was to return a few days ahead of the band.)" Judging from the Bain number for this negative, "6397-10" the picture could easily have been taken on the Paris, because the nearby picture of Nicholas Longworth has the number "6397-8" would have been taken on the Paris. Legendary balloonist and Goodyear engineer, Ward Van Orman (1894-1978) with partner Carl K. Wollam (1893-1960[?]), photographed after (given the "6/25/25" date inscription) their adventurous participation the 1925 Gordon Bennett Trophy Race. As per Wikipedia: en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ward_Van_Orman
During the 1925 International Race Van Orman performed world's first emergency night landing of a balloon on a deck of a steamship at high seas. The race took off June 9, 1925 at Brussels; at first the Goodyear III balloon floated over France towards Spain but then a change in wind dragged it into Atlantic Ocean. Van Orman's partner, Carl Wollam, desperate about inevitable death by drowning, intoxicated himself with cognac and attempted suicide at least twice. As Van Orman struggled to restrain Wollam from jumping overboard, he noticed navigation lights of a ship that turned out to be a small German freighter, Vaterland. Van Orman flashed morse code messages to the captain, who assisted the landing by turning on all available lighting and steering the ship towards the descending balloon. The balloon safely landed on Vaterland's forward deck. Van Orman and captain Rudolf Norman remained friends for life. This flight was the longest in the 1925 International Race, but Van Orman was disqualified and denied the Gordon Bennett Trophy according to the race rules requiring landing to be on land. Fifty years after this event, Van Orman was still bitterly hurt by the disqualification: "the memory of that unfair decision never has grown dim".
This would be far from the last of Van Orman's aviation adventures and achievements in a remarkably lived life.

C. K. Wollam and W.T. Van Orman, American balloonists, who took part in the Brussels balloon race and were picked up at sea by a freight steamer. They arrived in New York yesterday aboard the Leviathan." So the Bain picture will presumably have been taken on the Leviathan.

Lawrence Ray Weishaar (1890-1924) www.wikidata.org/wiki/Q7298270

Ray Weishaar was one of the most popular motorcycle racing stars of the 1910s and 1920s. Nicknamed the Kansas Cyclone, he became part of the Harley-Davidson’s “Wrecking Crew” in 1916. The team’s mascot was a small pig, which they took around the track on victory laps. Because of this mascot, Harley-Davidson motorcycles are called “hogs.” Discover more images highlighting arts, sports, and leisure in the Not an Ostrich exhibit (available online and in person!). www.loc.gov/exhibitions/images-from-americas-library/abou...

On May 21, 1881, Clara Barton hosted the first official meeting of the American Red Cross at her Washington, D.C., home. The organization continues to provide humanitarian aid during conflicts and natural disasters.

The American National Red Cross Collection in the Library's Prints and Photographs Division, offers a visual record of their accomplishments in providing relief throughout the world, primarily in the 1910s through the 1940s.

Still an active club: * millreefclub.ag/ "Mill Reef was founded in 1947 by Robertson ("Happy") Ward, a visionary architect, who foresaw the demand for travel in the aftermath of World War II. Ward aimed to create a private resort where like-minded people of diverse interests could vacation. He chose Antigua for its white sand beaches, turquoise waters and steady breezes. ... Original building rules stated that houses were to be simply designed, could have no more than two bedrooms and could cost no more than $25,000 to build! Ward recruited members by word-of-mouth throughout U.S. cities in the Northeast and Midwest, and across the British Commonwealth. The initial 45 Proprietary members paid $7,500 for their home lots. ... These funds financed construction of a clubhouse that opened for guests in 1949. A nine-hole golf course followed in 1953. Early Proprietary members included U.S. industrialists such as DuPont, Mott, Gould, Watson, Cowles, Endicott and (from across the ‘pond') Astor, as well as diplomats like Dean Acheson and the poet Archibald MacLeish." The History section on the home page for the club has a slide "carousel" that includes a crop from this picture as the last picture but one.

"Soldiers and Sailors Memorial Hall and Museum (or often simply Soldiers and Sailors Memorial Hall) is a National Register of Historic Places landmark in Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania, United States. It is the largest memorial in the United States dedicated solely to honoring all branches of military veterans and service personnel. It was conceived by the Grand Army of the Republic in the 1890s as a way for Pittsburgh and Allegheny County to honor the dwindling ranks of its American Civil War veterans; it was built on what had served as the army mustering ground during the Civil War. The Memorial today represents all branches of the service and honors both career and citizen soldiers who have served the United States throughout its history. Architect Henry Hornbostel designed the memorial in 1907. Dedicated in 1910, the building is in the Beaux-Arts style and is heroic in scale."

Definitely Nimes, and I wonder if it may be by Edouard Balthus? It also appears to be reversed - either in the scanning or in the printing of the original stereograph. Compare this image by Balthus: art.rmngp.fr/fr/library/artworks/edouard-baldus_vue-inter... You can see three large-blocked vertical buttresses almost in the centre of the LOC image on the left of Balthus's, but the arch to the left of the buttresses here is on the right in the Balthus. Thanks for the suggestions [https://www.flickr.com/photos/fraserpettigrew]. I couldn't find any proof that Edouard Baldus took stereograph photos at Nimes, so we'll hold off on that for now, but if anyone can find examples, we'll take a look. fineartamerica.com/featured/resurrection-of-the-dead-henn... has a relevant description for a similar work: "This is another in a series of sculptures by Hennetier & Habert, titled Diableries, which were sculptures in relief, which were then photographed by Hennetier with 2 camera lenses so as to appear in 3 dimensions, circa 1860's. This was scanned directly from the original which I purchased in Mexico City 25 years ago. This series featured various undertakings of the Devil, aka, Devilments. Crazy amount of work to go into each scene. These pre-date the stop motion clay animation sculpture by Ray Harryhausen by 100 years." See also londonstereo.com/diableries/index.html This doesn't look to be a Diablerie, but surely was made with the same technique.

In this panel from Gasoline Alley, Walt Wallet displays paternal spirit as he takes his adopted son on a hike, where they encounter a bear and escape. Did you know that Gasoline Alley creator Frank King portrayed his characters aging in real time, an innovative development in comics. Today, "baby" Skeezix is an elderly man with a large extended family in what is now the longest running comic strip in the United States. Find more visual and narrative storytelling styles from newspaper panels and comic images in the Comic Art: 120 Years of Panels and Pages exhibit, available online. loc.gov/exhibitions/comic-art/about-this-exhibition/

Photojournalist Marjory Collins snapped these two women while documenting a night out for the Office of War Information (many sailors there were enjoying a final night of leave). Collins started her documentary photographic career after selling her wedding silver to buy a camera. From 1942-1943, she traveled the United States, completing 50 assignments that captured American life.

In 1900, Booker T. Washington (second from left) founded the National Negro Business League to promote African-American businesses. This League was supported by philanthropist Andrew Carnegie. By 1915, there were over 600 chapters in 34 states.

National Negro Business League www.wikidata.org/wiki/Q6974564 I am working on assigning names to all the people here: commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:National_Negro_Business_L... I have loaded a list of the executive committee and some images of attendees from the first meeting. The above image is not the initial meeting in 1900, several key people are missing. We know it is earlier than 1914, the year Booker T. Washington died. See also this 1910 image from Bain: commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:Roosevelt_speaking_at_Nat... The tenth convention of the National Negro Business League was held at the Palm Garden Theatre, New York City from August 17, 1910 to August 19, 1910.

Based on the picture at top of www.blackpast.org/african-american-history/scott-emmett-j... I think that second from left standing could be Emmett J. Scott (1873-1957), who was corresponding secretary of the National Negro Business League in 1904. "Scott caught the attention of Booker T. Washington, who hired him in 1897. For the next eighteen years, Scott served Washington as a confidant, personal secretary, speech writer, and ghostwriter; in 1912, he became Tuskegee’s treasurer-secretary. Scott advocated Washington’s philosophy of constructive accommodation over immediate social integration. Scott and New York Age editor T. Thomas Fortune helped Washington found the National Negro Business League (NNBL) in 1900."

en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tom_Mix "Thomas Edwin Mix (born Thomas Hezikiah Mix; January 6, 1880 – October 12, 1940) was an American film actor and the star of many early Western films between 1909 and 1935. He appeared in 291 films, all but nine of which were silent films. He was Hollywood's first Western star and helped define the genre as it emerged in the early days of the cinema." His wife in this picture is Victoria Forde and their daughter is Thomasina. See cowgirlmagazine.com/wild-women-of-the-west-victoria-forde/ en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Victoria_Forde

April 07, 1925, page 10, column 6, bottom chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn82014248/1925-04-07/ed-... reported, "Tom Mix To Sail Tonight On 'Aquitania' -- Tom Mix., motion picture star, with his family, his horse and trappings will sail for Europe tonight at midnight on the Cunard liner 'Aquitania'. He will tour Great Britain and the continent, giving exhibitions of Western horsemanship in many of the large cities. Tom Mix was formerly deputy city marshal of Dewey, Okla., and Is an expert with horses, revolvers and lariats. He will be accompanied by his wife, his daughter Thomasina. and his mother-in-law, Mrs. Forde. The family will occupy the regal suite, consisting of four staterooms, a parlor, a veranda and two bath rooms."

Time 1927 Trans-Atlantic flight. Thank you for sharing the photo! I just wrote a review, but for his book "Alone" about the first Antarctic expedition 1928–1930 here. archive.org/details/alonebyrd00byrd Great human character! 👍

Byrd lead teams of aviators in expeditions to the Arctic in 1925 and 1926. Floyd Bennett, in nearby photo in the Bain stream also flew in those expeditions. Noville, also in a nearby photo in the Bain stream, flew with them in the Arctic in 1926.

The image is found in the Casper Daily Tribune May 4, 1925. In the other image of Byrd he is holding an inflatable raft, he appears to have tested his "feather boat" on the Potomac River on April 27, 1925 per Evening Star "Bladder lifeboat for Arctic Flight is Tried out Here". The plane is a Vought VE-7 (en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Vought_VE-7), and the other man in the image before this appears to be Lt. M.E. Schur. Sources: Casper daily tribune. See Evening Star. December 01, 1919, page 15, col 5. chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn83045462/1919-12-01/ed-... ===> DISTRICT TO HAVE A P.O. ON WHEELS What is believed will be the first post office on wheels in the United States is to make its appearance on the streets of Washington before the end of the week in connection with the opening of the city post office's "mail early campaign" for Christmas. A big three-ton truck is being converted into a miniature post office which will be run daily to some prominent corner downtown and remain there for the reception of Christmas parcels. City Postmaster Chance declared today that if the "Xmas post office," as it will be called, proves a success. probably it will be retained as a permanent "office on wheels." * Office Described * Three clerks will be stationed in the "office," which will occupy a space about 6 by 8 feet in the front of the truck. There will be a counter, and a "lobby" for patrons. Entrance will be from the rear of the truck, up a flights of steps, through a door on the right. Exit will be by a door on the left. "Everything except chairs" will be provided for the convenience of patrons. There will be electric lights and heat and full facilities for mailing parcels. * Will Be at War Risk Bureau. * It Is probable that the "Xmas post office" will be stationed In front of the war risk insurance bureau on its first trip, which probably will be made Saturday morning. Present plans call for the stationing of the truck at various busy corners, the schedule to be announced later. When the ambulating post office Is filled with parcels. It will "up anchor" and swiftly proceed to the city post office, and then run downtown again. Should a great rush be made upon it, this plan will be abandoned, and mail will be taken from it hourly as the office fills up. Five easy steps will give easy access to the "lobby" of the post office on wheels. ===>

To reduce the cost of transferring an original letter through the military postal system, a V-mail letter would be censored, copied to film, and printed back to paper upon arrival at its destination. The V-mail process is based on the earlier British Airgraph process."

Ralph Budd (1879-1962) www.wikidata.org/wiki/Q7287283

Ralph Budd (August 20, 1879 - February 2, 1962) was an American railroad executive who was the president of the Great Northern Railway from 1919 up until 1932, when he served as president of the Chicago, Burlington and Quincy Railroad until his retirement in 1949.

Budd is the man standing. See nose shape in www.nrrhof.org/ralph-budd and collections.mnhs.org/mnhistorymagazine/articles/65/v65i01... The date 4/13/25 is written on the negative. In the Spring of 1925, he spent time on the West Coast and in the Pacific Northwest. The Seattle Star. April 10, 1925, Page 20, col. 4, top. chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn87093407/1925-04-10/ed-... says, "G. N. Plans Reconstruction of 30 Miles Thru Mountains. Thirty miles of track on the Great Northern railroad thru the Cascades will be electrified, it was announced Friday by Ralph Budd, president of the road, who arrived In Seattle Thursday night to supervise the construction work. Actual construction will start as soon as contracts, now being figured on, can be closed. Plans are already complete. The electrified track of the main line will be between Skykomish on this side of the mountains and Verne, the first station after the eastern end of the Cascade tunnel." It seems likely that in this photo, Budd is talking to people with an interest in the electrification project or track extensions that were also in the works. collections.mnhs.org/mnhistorymagazine/articles/65/v65i01... is an article by Randal O’Toole from Minnesota History magazine Spring 2016. It describes tours he arranged on the railroad going west from Chicago and stopping at places of historical interest. It begins: "In 1925 and 1926, the Great Northern Railway sponsored two trips unlike any rail tours before or since. In preparation, the railway erected six historic monuments that remain to this day, commissioned numerous papers on the history of the Northwest, convinced the U.S. Post Office to rename several places so as to reflect their history, and invited prominent historians, state governors, a former chief of staff of the U.S. Army, and a U.S. Supreme Court justice to give talks at various points along the way. These tours were the brainchild of Great Northern president Ralph Budd. An Iowa farm boy who received his degree in civil engineering at the age of 19, Budd was a self-made intellectual with deep interests in history, literature, art, and technology, all of which he brought together for the railway’s two historical expeditions."

Oskar Albinus "Albin" Stenroos was a Finnish runner, who won the marathon at the 1924 Olympics. Stenroos ran his first marathon in 1909, placing third at the national championships, but then moved to shorter distances, down to 1500 m.

In the Evening Star. April 20, 1925, Page 25, col 3, middle chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn83045462/1925-04-20/ed-... reported an "announcement made by Stenroos at the home of Hugo Quist, American trainer and adviser to Paavo Nurmi, at 210 West 147th street, where the Olympic marathon champion is making his headquarters temporarily. Stenroos spent yesterday sightseeing through the city with Carl Kolehmainen, younger brother of Hannes Kolehmainen, and renewing acquaintances with countrymen scattered through the city. Willie Kolehmainen, older brother of the great Hannes, acted as guide for the visitors."
Thanks everyone, we'll update our catalog record.
Juho Pietari "Hannes" Kolehmainen (; 9 December 1889 – 11 January 1966) was a Finnish four-time Olympic Gold medalist and a world record holder in middle- and long-distance running

The sports news in 1925, the date of the photos in this batch of Bain photos, featured comparisons between Paavo Nurmi, who was in the U.S. in 1925 with his countryman who had come 12 years earlier. According to the Evening Star. January 22, 1925, Page 30 chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn83045462/1925-01-22/ed-... "Hannes Kolehmainen, who came out of the Stockholm Olympic of 1912 to apply for membership in the Irish-American A. C. in New York, become an American citizen and shatter about every record in the United States for 2’4 to 10 miles, is surpassed. Kolehmainen, when he came here 12 years ago, was heralded as the superathlete, and it was believed that the marks he created would stand forever. Yet, a few years later, there was destined to come forth still a greater runner in the person of Paavo Nurmi, the draftsman of Abo. Until last night many of the figures had withstood every onslaught. Nurmi shattered two, to run his total of new world records made in this country to 10, and might have broken another had he kept his eyes on his stopwatch. See also the Evening Star. March 24, 1925, Page 21, col 4, top chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn83045462/1925-03-24/ed-... under the headline "KOLEHMAINEN AS GREAT IN HIS DAY AS NURMI." This picture of Kolehmainen may have been taken before 1925.

The initials are not right for Hannes. This photo is probably of Hannes' younger brother Carl who took Albin Stenroos, seen in the neighboring photo in the Bain stream sightseeing round New York city on April 19, according to the Evening Star. April 20, 1925, Page 25, col. 3, middle chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn83045462/1925-04-20/ed-... Perhaps Carl Kolehmainen met Stenroos on the boat when he arrived.

Nice sleuthing  [https://www.flickr.com/photos/23103743@N05]. I found a New York Herald article which says Carl accompanied Stenroos on the trip. Apparently there was another Kolehmainen brother, Willie, who "acted as translator". We'll put Carl's name in the catalog record.

A visual diary brings to life the wartime experience of noted architect Victor A. Lundy, who served in the U.S. 26th Infantry Division during World War II. Lundy (turning 100 on February 1, 2023) applied his drawing skills to what was around him and many vivid portraits of fellow soldiers and frontline danger fill the pages. The eight surviving sketchbooks are spiral bound and 3 x 5 inches --small enough to fit in a breast pocket. Lundy sketched quickly. "For me, drawing is sort of synonymous with thinking." guides.loc.gov/lundy-world-war-ii-sketches

It's National Braille Literacy Month (January) and a great time to highlight the exciting work from the National Library Service for the Blind and Print Disabled. This free national library program provides braille and recorded materials to people who cannot see regular print or handle print materials. www.loc.gov/nls/

An article by Frederic J. Haskin in January 1922 was published in many newspapers to judge from the number found in Chronicling America. See, for example, the Perth Amboy Evening News. January 13, 1922, FINAL EDITION, Page 14, under the cartoon chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn85035720/1922-01-13/ed-... with the heading "HASKIN TELLS OF BOOKS FOR THE BLIND." It begins "WASHINGTON, Jan. 10.—Making books for blind veterans Is the newest kind of "after the war work” to become popular. Knitting needles and embroidery hoops are being discarded for the metal slate and stylus with which Braille books are hand written. Clubs and Red Cross chapters are busily punching out stories and articles in the code of dotswhich is the blind man's closest connecting link with written thought. There is always a need for books for the blind. The big cities have their Braille libraries, but the selection of books on the shelves is always limited. The novel you buy for a dollar or two and tuck in your overcoat pocket would cost $20 in Braille and would fill three or more large tomes. Libraries for the blind are slowly growing all the time, but since the war blind have been added to the number to be provided with Braille reading matter, the Red Cross decided that extra effort was needed. For three years six chapters of the Red Cross have been making Braille books. Last fall the National Red Cross arranged to make this work a part of the national program. Courses in Braille writing were prepared by Mrs. Gertrude T. Rider, librarian of the Room for the Blind in the Library of Congress. Certificates were prepared for those who should master the system in order to make books for the soldiers. Miss Adelia Hoyt of the Reading Room for the Blind says that for the present all books made by the volunteers will go to Evergreen, the institute established by the Red Cross at Baltimore for training blinded soldiers and sailors. Later, it is planned to send books to big circulating libraries for civilian blind." The article describes several ways in which Braille can be produced, including typewriters. "The Braille typewriter is another of the three means of making books for the blind. The typewriter has only six keys, one for each dot that may be used in a letter. To make a letter, the proper keys are struck simultaneously, like a c[h]ord. The typewriter is a more speedy instrument than the slate, but it is considerably more expensive, costing about $32."

See also * timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1921/11/13/11332286... * timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1925/08/02/99352292... * timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1924/04/13/10159017... This article states that "Nearly fifty Red Cross workers are continually at work producing Braille books for the blinded veterans, and all years classes are conducted at the Red Cross Teaching Centre at 24 Fifth Avenue."

Rev. Leonard Grimes (1815-1873) dedicated his life to helping enslaved people escape.

In 1839, Grimes rescued an enslaved woman, Patty, and her six children. After his release from two years of punitive hard labor, he moved to Boston and became first pastor of the Twelfth Baptist Church—a.k.a. “The Fugitives Church,” for having many self-emancipated congregation members. There, he continued his abolitionist work and bought enslaved people’s freedom. Today, he is remembered for his open defiance of the Fugitive Slave Act and for helping hundreds of freedom-seekers make it to Canada.

Carlos Sedano, Spanish violinist. See www.holdridgerecords.com/auction_pdfs/12.7_instrumental_7... "CARLOS SEDANO [violinist]. 1905-1977 [various other sources give his dates as 1903-1978]. A Spanish violinist, Sedano had been successful in Spain as a prodigy but came to New York to continue studies with Leopold Auer when the celebrated teacher emigrated to the U.S. from Russia. Sedano’s New York debut was at Carnegie Hall in 1924, where the NY Times reviewer noted his “considerable artistic as well as physical stature”. At 19, he was taller than his accompanist, the six-foot-plus Richard Hageman. Subsequently he appeared in New York at Aeolian Hall, where he performed “as a sensitive and able musician” and in a number of recitals in private homes and for charity. Sedano made test sides for Victor in 1924 and at least one Vitaphone short in 1927, but his only published recordings were three discs for Columbia in 1926, these apparently issued principally in South America. Other than for the above period of his life, information on Sedano has proven scant." See also www.discogs.com/artist/11665895-Carlos-Sedano-2 and data.carnegiehall.org/events/12598/about and the Musical Observer, Volume 24, January 1925, page 23 books.google.com/books?id=VfhjZBE87FgC&pg=PA23&lp...
His debut was on October 19, 1924. See New York Times of Oct 20, 1924 -- second column of PDF timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1924/10/20/11904506...

Sedano is using a Kodak No 3A Autographic camera.  The 3A camera produced a large 3 1/4" x 5 1/2" negative on A122 roll film. The "autographic" part referred to a little hinged door on the camera back where the photographer could write some small notes on the film with a stylus - an early form of EXIF data? Not really a camera for the hobbyist but for a photographer on  assignment it could be handy. Interestingly, this camera has a relatively basic 2 speed Kodex No. 1 shutter. While the 3A was introduced in 1916, it wasn't offered with the Kodex until 1925, suggesting that this was a brand new camera.

Helen Hayes MacArthur (née Brown; October 10, 1900 – March 17, 1993) was an American actress whose career spanned 80 years. She eventually received the nickname "First Lady of American Theatre" and was the second person and first woman to have won an Emmy, a Grammy, an Oscar, and a Tony Award (an EGOT). She was also the first person to win the Triple Crown of Acting; to date, the only other person to have accomplished both is Rita Moreno. Hayes also received the Presidential Medal of Freedom, America's highest civilian honor, from President Ronald Reagan in 1986. In 1988, she was awarded the National Medal of Arts.

The Flonzaley Quartet was a string quartet organized in Manhattan, New York City in 1902. The group disbanded in 1929. The members are : 
    1st violin: Adolfo Betti [it; ru] (Bagni di Lucca, 21 March 1875 – Lucca, 2 December 1950).
    2nd violin: Alfred Pochon (Yverdon, 30 July 1878 – Lutry, 26 February 1959).
    viola: Ugo Ara (Venezia, 1876 – Lausanne, 1 December 1936), until 1917; replaced by Louis Bailly (Valenciennes, 13 June 1882 – Cowansville, Québec, 21 November 1974), until 1924; by Félicien d'Archambeau (? – ?), until 1925; by Nicolas Moldavan (Kremenetz, 23 January 1891 – New York, 21 September 1974), until disbanding in 1928.
    violoncello: Iwan d'Archambeau (Herve, 1879 – Villefranche-sur-Mer, 29 December 1955).

Frances Benjamin Johnston (1864-1952) was one of the first American women to achieve prominence as a photographer. Trained at the Académie Julian in Paris, she studied photography upon her return to Washington, D.C., in the mid-1880s and opened a professional studio circa 1890. Her family's social position gave Johnston access to the First Family and leading Washington political figures and launched her career as a photojournalist and portrait photographer. View her collection, which includes garden and estate photography from the 1910s, in the Library catalog. www.loc.gov/pictures/collection/fbj/

Sarah Bernhardt (French: [saʁa bɛʁnɑʁt];[note 1] born Henriette-Rosine Bernard; 22 or 23 October 1844 – 26 March 1923) was a French stage actress who starred in some of the most popular French plays of the late 19th and early 20th centuries, including La Dame Aux Camelias by Alexandre Dumas fils; Ruy Blas by Victor Hugo, Fédora and La Tosca by Victorien Sardou, and L'Aiglon by Edmond Rostand. She also played male roles, including Shakespeare's Hamlet. Rostand called her "the queen of the pose and the princess of the gesture", while Hugo praised her "golden voice". She made several theatrical tours around the world, and was one of the first prominent actresses to make sound recordings and to act in motion pictures.

In 1880, at the start of her first tour to the United States, an article in the [New Haven] Morning Journal and Courier. October 30, 1880, page 1, right-hand column chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn82015483/1880-10-30/ed-... focused on her costumes for the roles she was to play and that "the great Felix, prince of Paris dressmakers, was subjected to the most trying variations of her taste. The making of the dresses is described in the Figaro as a perfect work of art, for Bernhardt required the most delicate variations of light and shade." But there is no mention of an "Ocean Empress" as role or name of a play.

Another photo of Bernhardt in the LoC collections is www.loc.gov/pictures/item/98503044/resource/ in which Bernhardt is in the diver suit. Both pictures appear to have been acquired through copyright deposit in the U.S. Perhaps they were promotional photographs for a project she was trying to get support for. Jules Verne's "20,000 Leagues under the Seas" originated in serialized form in 1869-70, with an octavo illustrated edition published in 1871. See en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Twenty_Thousand_Leagues_Under_the_Seas The popularity of the novel and the illustrations showing similar suits for men on the sea floor might have inspired Bernhardt.

The Copyright Office has a browsing system for hand-written catalog cards from 1870-1897.  I don't fully understand the catalog structure but I have been able to determine that the photographer Napoleon Sarony submitted at least 40 photographs in 1880 that appear in groups under cards with the heading Bernhardt, Sarah.  They are also listed in groups under cards with the heading Sarony (N).  But I have not found captions for individual photographs.

This photo was held in the LoC's BIOG file and has a 4 written on it. Also in the file, with a 5 in the same hand is www.loc.gov/pictures/item/98503044/resource/ a photo of Bernhardt in another studio portrait. In this one, she is wearing the diver suit and holding the helmet. She and some props are in front of a painted backdrop of sea and cloudy sky.
The woman in the photo is not identified as Sarah Bernhardt, but rather as Miss Bernhardt. If you compare this Miss Bernhardt to Sarah Bernhardt you will see that they are not the same person.

[https://www.flickr.com/photos/192681601@N08] 

However, the neighboring photo of the same woman is identified as Sarah Bernhardt in a subject heading.  I have been looking at lots of photos of Sarah Bernhardt and she can look quite different depending on the lighting and the character she is assuming as well as the camera angle.  Is there another Miss Bernhardt who would warrant being included in the BIOG file?

The Buckau, the first vehicle to be propelled by a Flettner rotor. A Flettner rotor is a smooth cylinder with disc end plates which is spun along its long axis and, as air passes at right angles across it, the Magnus effect causes an aerodynamic force to be generated in the direction perpendicular to both the long axis and the direction of airflow

Found this info on Mary Evans Picture Library.
This information was attached to a different picture of the same ship.

The Rotor Ship Buckau, 1924

Photograph of the experimental Rotor ship Buckau, on sea trials, 1924. Anton Flettner equipped the 680 ton schooner, Buckau, with two rotating cylindrical towers to test his Flettner rudder . With the wind in the right place and the cylinders rotating, Flettner believed he could create a sail that was 15 times more efficient than a canvas sail of the same size. Trials showed he was right, but the technology was not reliable enough to encourage commercial use

© Illustrated London News Ltd/Mary Evans

Hotel New Netherland (later Hotel Netherland) was located at the northeast corner of Fifth Avenue and 59th Street, in Manhattan, New York City, New York, in what is now the Upper East Side Historic District. It contained the Sherry's restaurant from 1919 until its demolition in 1927.
www.wikidata.org/wiki/Q19361341

The ca. 1912 photo in en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hotel_New_Netherland shows a different building (or at least different facade) to the left of the hotel. The building was probably 785 Fifth Avenue. The New Britain Herald. December 06, 1924, Page 5, column 2 chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn82014519/1924-12-06/ed-... reports that the hotel was sold by the estate of Baron William Waldorf Astor to Frederick Brown, who paid cash for the building which was assessed by the city at $2,100,000. That accounts for the fact that Bain had the photo filed with other pictures from that month. The Evening Star. May 10, 1925, Page 18, column 6, near top chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn83045462/1925-05-10/ed-... reported that the hotel "closed its doors today. The building will be converted into stores and apartments." The Wikipedia article linked above indicates that the building was demolished in 1927 and replaced by a new hotel, the Sherry-Netherland, which was an apartment hotel. From en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Sherry-Netherland "Demolition began in the early winter of 1926, and construction began before the year was out, but the upper floors suffered a spectacular fire when wooden scaffolding caught alight on April 12, 1927 before the building was completed. The fire burned for 12 hours and flames were said to have been visible from Long Island. It ignited a debate in the press concerning the ability of the available technology to put out fires in high-rise buildings."

Millicent Veronica Hearst (née Willson; July 16, 1882 – December 5, 1974), was the wife of media tycoon William Randolph Hearst. Willson was a vaudeville performer in New York City whom Hearst admired, and they married in 1903. The couple had five sons, but began to drift apart in the mid-1920s, when Millicent became tired of her husband's longtime affair with actress Marion Davies.

[https://www.flickr.com/photos/puzzlemaster] What a fantastic detail. And maybe a challenge to the approximate date in the details?

The date written on the negative is 12/16/24. Bain usually wrote dates on negatives either when the picture was taken or later when it was published because it was relevant to current new. Most of the photos from this batch are from December 1924. Mrs. Hearst was not in the news in December 1924, but was touring Europe in late 1924. The Washington Times. October 17, 1924, page 1, column 1 chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn84026749/1924-10-17/ed-... reported that she was touring Europe and had been received that day by Premier Benito Mussolini. One possibility is that she returned from Europe on December 16, 1924.

Thanks everyone for the comments and suggestions. I'll make sure we add her name to the catalog record. As to the date issue, I searched around and found a Dec. 11, 1924 entry in the NY Herald Tribune which says "Mrs. William Randolph Hearst sailed from Europe on Tuesday" (Tuesday would have been Dec. 9th). So, I think the 1924 date is correct.
Thanks to everyone for correcting my hasty assumption.

Gladys Louise Smith (April 8, 1892 – May 29, 1979), known professionally as Mary Pickford, was a Canadian-American stage and screen actress and producer with a career that spanned five decades. A pioneer in the US film industry, she co-founded Pickford–Fairbanks Studios and United Artists, and was one of the 36 founders of the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences.[3] Pickford is considered to be one of the most recognisable women in history.[4]
Charlotte Hennessey Smith (Pickford) (January 1, 1873 – March 22, 1928) was a Canadian silent film actress and the mother of Mary, Lottie, and Jack Pickford, who all became actors.
Joseph Michael Schenck (/ˈskɛŋk/; December 25, 1876[1] – October 22, 1961) was a Russian-born American film studio executive.
Hiram Abrams (22 February 1878 – 15 November 1926) was an early American movie mogul and one of the first presidents of Paramount Pictures. He was also the first managing director of United Artists.

Sir Charles Spencer Chaplin Jr. KBE (16 April 1889 – 25 December 1977) was an English comic actor, filmmaker, and composer who rose to fame in the era of silent film. He became a worldwide icon through his screen persona, the Tramp, and is considered one of the film industry's most important figures. His career spanned more than 75 years, from childhood in the Victorian era until a year before his death in 1977, and encompassed both adulation and controversy.

Douglas Elton Fairbanks Sr.[1] (born Douglas Elton Thomas Ullman; May 23, 1883 – December 12, 1939) was an American actor, screenwriter, director, and producer.[2] He was best known for his swashbuckling roles in silent films including The Thief of Bagdad, Robin Hood, and The Mark of Zorro, but spent the early part of his career making comedies.

According to A STATEMENT OF FINANCES AND ACCOMPLISHMENTS FOR THE PERIOD JULY 1, 1917 TO FEBRUARY 28, 1919 AMERICAN RED CROSS WASHINGTON, D. C. OCTOBER, 1919 available online at www.vlib.us/medical/ARC/ARC2.htm "The first war drive was conducted between June I8 and June 25, 1917. The goal set was $100,000,000. Collections totaled $114,023,640.23, an over-subscription of fourteen per cent. For campaign and collection expenses national headquarters appropriated $278,114.27, and it is estimated that the chapters spent $500,000 for this purpose; costs, therefore, were less than seven-tenths of one cent for each dollar collected. The second war drive was conducted between May 20 and May 27, 1918. Again the goal set was $100,000,000. Up to February 28, 1919, collections totaled $169,575,598.84, an over-subscription of nearly seventy per cent. (It is estimated that when all collections have been received the total will exceed $175,000,000, an over-subscription of more than seventy-five per cent.) Campaign and collection expenses totaled approximately $1,000,000---less than six-tenths of one cent for each dollar collected."

See en.wikipedia.org/wiki/USS_New_Hampshire_(1864) "New Hampshire was towed from Newport to New London, Connecticut in 1891 and was receiving ship there until decommissioned on 5 June 1892. The following year she was loaned as a training ship for the New York Naval Militia, which was to furnish nearly a thousand officers and men to the Navy during the Spanish–American War. New Hampshire was renamed Granite State on 30 November 1904 to free the name "New Hampshire" for a newly authorized battleship New Hampshire (BB-25). Stationed in the Hudson River, Granite State continued training service throughout the years leading to World War I when State naval militia were practically the only trained and equipped men available to the Navy for immediate service."

Nicholas Altrock (September 15, 1876 – January 20, 1965) was an American professional baseball player and coach. He played in Major League Baseball as a left-handed pitcher between 1898 and 1919. After the 1919 season he continued to make periodic appearances as a pinch hitter for many years, until his final game at the age of 57. As a player, Altrock was a member of two World Series winning teams and then, won a third World Series as a coach. He was a coach for the Washington Senators for many years.

Alexander Schacht (November 11, 1892 – July 14, 1984) was an American professional baseball player, coach, and, later, restaurateur. Schacht was a pitcher in the major leagues from 1919 to 1921 for the Washington Senators.
See also

George Herman "Babe" Ruth Jr. (February 6, 1895 – August 16, 1948) was an American professional baseball player whose career in Major League Baseball (MLB) spanned 22 seasons, from 1914 through 1935. Nicknamed "the Bambino" and "the Sultan of Swat", he began his MLB career as a star left-handed pitcher for the Boston Red Sox, but achieved his greatest fame as a slugging outfielder for the New York Yankees. Ruth is regarded as one of the greatest sports heroes in American culture and is considered by many to be the greatest baseball player of all time. In 1936, Ruth was elected into the Baseball Hall of Fame as one of its "first five" inaugural members.

[https://www.flickr.com/photos/jimhair] You have a great eye, Jim! Thank you for noticing that which I woulda' missed.

[https://www.flickr.com/photos/jimhair], Bain often went aboard ships leaving out of New York to take photos of well known people. My guess is that Mr. Spalding was on the deck taking photos and the Bain photographer thought it would be a funny to take a photo of him taking a photo (or at least acting like he was).

[https://www.flickr.com/photos/63860770@N07/] it must have been a popular activity. There is a classic photo of George Eastman aboard a ship with one of his first Kodak cameras. It created a round image.  ❤️

The Bain photographer would also take photos of ordinary women that were attractive and young on slow news days. We have about a dozen examples of them. We tracked down who they were in the census or found them mentioned as debutantes in the New York papers.

Luftschiff LZ 126, better known as the US Navy airship USS Los Angeles (ZR-3). The date written on the negative is 8/22/24. This could mean that it was taken in 1924, but one practice of the Bain studio was to apply a date when they used the photo later, often because the individual or event was in the news again. LoC does not apply exact dates without confirming evidence and described this photo as "circa 1900." Looking at the photos in en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Benito_Mussolini I personally think circa 1920 might be closer. In the Perth Amboy Evening News. April 03, 1924, FINAL EDITION, Page 3, bottom of column 4 chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn85035720/1924-04-03/ed-... is a photo that looks to be of him with a similar build.
www.gettyimages.com/detail/news-photo/italian-dictator-be... has a copy of this photo and dates it as September 1923. It also reckons the location is Biarritz.

Thanks [https://www.flickr.com/photos/23103743@N05] for looking into this photo and explaining to everyone how Bain's dating of photos worked. From my experience, it seems that Bain rarely sent their photographers outside New York City or the surrounding area. If you see a Bain photo taken in Europe then you can be fairly certain they made a copy of another photo, and the date is probably when the copy was made. 

I think we'll hold off on adding the date from the Getty Images copy since it also comes from a press agency (in that case, a British one) and I'm not sure if their dating is any more accurate than Bain's.

"Off to Vamp Votes for “Fighting Bob” NEW YORK, Sept. 17.—Miss Helen Jones and Miss Rosalie Todd stepped on the self-starter of a big car here today and started off on a trail-blazing pilgrimage through the Middle West, during which they will make “soap-box” speeches in behalf of the La Follette-Wheeler candidacy. They will tour the Middle West, stopping at farm houses to tell wives of the national issues. They will also make speeches on street corners afternoons and set speeches at night in the towns through which they pass. Miss Jones is a practicing lawyer and Miss Todd a well known social worker. They plan to make their first speeches at Poughkeepsie and Albany today."

While in Tunisia in 1924 filming The Arab Ingram met a young orphan named Kada abd-el-Kader. Ingram and his wife Alice Terry brought the boy back with them (on the Aquitania) to adopt an raise in America. While Kada went on to feature in Ingram's 1926 film Mare Nostrum, it turned out that Kada wasn't as young as he represented himself to be and after getting involved with "fast cars and fast women" was sent back to Morocco.

Note: Donald, not Dan

Donald L Samuels, 1901-1948 was an executive with the Manhattan Shirt Company. 

". . . and wife" is far more interesting. Donald met Charlotte (Lotte) Anna Emma Cramer on the tennis court at Marienbad in 1922 when she was 15. He returned to marry her two years later and bring her back to NY.  In this honeymoon photo she is 17 and he is 23 or 24. They divorced in 1930.

Ten years later she began her rise as a Muffin Mix Magnate when she founded Cramer Products Company and launched a successful line of Cake and Muffin mixes under the Joy Prepared Mixes brand. She later married Alexander Sachs. She later invented the retractable dog leash and the home wine cooler. She died in 2004 at age 96.

You can't make this stuff up.

A similar photo is at www.immigrantentrepreneurship.org/images/charlotte-cramer... with caption, "Charlotte Cramer Samuels and Donald Samuels (married September 12, 1924 in Berlin-Dahlem), aboard the S.S. Reliance en route from Hamburg to New York, October 1924." Other resources for Lotte include: * sova.si.edu/record/NMAH.AC.0878 Finding aid for Charlotte Cramer Sachs Papers at the Smithsonian * www.immigrantentrepreneurship.org/entries/charlotte-crame...

This ape was known as Hugh Mongous See www.pilotonline.com/history/article_561da963-602f-5755-91... "If you grew up in Hampton Roads, chances are you spent some of your summer vacations at what was once called Jungle Falls, later expanded and renamed Wild Water Rapids and then expanded again and finally called Ocean Breeze Water Park. Of course we all remember who greeted us at the entrance to the park. 'Hugh Mongous' 65-foot-tall, 45,000-pound foam and fiberglass ape was a General Booth Boulevard landmark for a decade until the early morning hours of January 3, 1989. That morning, responding to reports of a dumpster fire, firefighters discovered the giant statue burning in the morning darkness like a giant Roman candle. Fire enveloped the ape from his toes to at least 10 feet above his head. It took firefighters 15 minutes to put out the flaming ape."

Since 2004, the month of August marks National Black Business Month.

en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Toti_Dal_Monte "Antonietta Meneghel (27 June 1893 – 26 January 1975), better known by her stage name Toti Dal Monte, was a celebrated Italian operatic soprano." In late 1924, there were many announcements in newspapers of future concerts and her engagement by the Chicago Civic Opera to sing the title role in Lucia di Lammermoor. Recordings in that role were also featured in a large Victor advertisement. See, e.g., New Britain Herald. September 11, 1924, Page 2 chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn82014519/1924-09-11/ed-... "Dal Monte's Victor Records precede her American debut Again Victor Records herald in America one of Europe's great voices-that of Toti Dal Monte, premiere soprano of La Scala Opera in Milan. .Nothing more strongly typifies Victor service to music-lovers than the recording in Europe of this talented lyric soprano's voice and the announcement of her first Victor Record before her American debut." The Daily Worker. November 07, 1924, page 3, column 3 chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn84020097/1924-11-07/ed-... indicates that her debut as Lucia would be in Chicago on the coming Monday. From www.oxfordreference.com/view/10.1093/oi/authority.2011080... "It. soprano. Début Milan 1916 (Biancafiore in Zandonai's Francesca da Rimini). Sang Gilda in Rigoletto cond. Toscanini, Milan 1922. Regular operatic appearances in It., also Chicago 1924–8; NY Met 1924–5; CG 1925. Farewell appearance Verona 1949. Became teacher."

The curved detail on the top edge of the wall places Mayor Hylan at the Polo Grounds, as he poses prior to throwing out a ceremonial first pitch. (See comment by Jon (LOC P&P) below). The date inscribed (in reverse) on the bottom of image reads "10/6/24," which would make the occasion Game 3 of the 1924 World Series, between the New York Giants and Washington Senators. The first game of the series to be played at the Polo Grounds. The Giants would defeat the Senators that day, by a score of 6-4, but the Senators would ultimately win the World Series (their first World Series Championship) in seven games. Boxing champion Jack Dempsey en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jack_Dempsey He was the second husband of Estelle Taylor en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Estelle_Taylor "Ida Estelle Taylor (May 20, 1894 – April 15, 1958) was an American actress, singer, model, and animal rights activist. With 'dark-brown, almost black hair and brown eyes,' she was regarded as one of the most beautiful silent film stars of the 1920s." and this looks like her. From her Wikipedia entry: "Taylor and Dempsey were married on February 7, 1925 at First Presbyterian Church in San Diego, California. They lived in Los Feliz, Los Angeles. Her marriage to Dempsey ended in divorce on September 21, 1931." Kendrick en.wikipedia.org/wiki/W._Freeland_Kendrick was Mayor of Philadelphia 1924-1928

In 1926, Philadelphia had a Sesquicentennial celebration, in which Dempsey had some involvement. See NYT of August 23, 1926 timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1926/08/23/98852419... in which Dempsey "expects to go to Philadelphia to lunch with Mayor Kendrick." Given the date written on the negative, it seems likely that the Dempseys had visited Kendrick earlier in the year. In February, Kendrick had voiced opposition to having a fight as part of the sesquicentennial event. See NYT of Feb 16, 1926 timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1926/02/17/10005044... The date written on the negative, which looks to be 6/25/26, would have been in the first month of the event.

The image appears to be Left to Right: *Mayor W. Freeland Kendrick of Philadelphia (en.wikipedia.org/wiki/W._Freeland_Kendrick) *Gene Normile, Dempsey's Manager *Estelle Taylor, Dempsey's Wife *Jack Dempsey (en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jack_Dempsey) The date on the photograph may be incorrect, and could have been taken between August 22, 1926 when Dempsey visited Philadelphia in advance of the fight later in September against Gene Tunney. Source: Photo of the same individuals in the same clothing from Acme Photos. Evening star. [volume] (Washington, D.C.), 25 Aug. 1926. Chronicling America: Historic American Newspapers. Winner of 18 Grand Slam Championships, Alice Marble's tennis legacy extends far beyond the court. 

In July 1950, she wrote an editorial demanding that Althea Gibson be allowed to play (Gibson competed in the US Open that next month). Marble also coached a young Billie Jean Moffitt, or Billie Jean King as many know her today.

On July 12, 1976, Barbara Jordan became the first woman and first Black keynote address speaker at the Democratic National Convention. 

Jordan served in the Texas State Senate from 1967-1973 and then the U.S. House of Representatives from 1973-1979. She was the first Black woman from a Southern state to join Congress.

Rita Senger's drawing for the July 1916 cover of Vanity Fair projects a bold sensation of bodily freedom. The American Beauties online exhibition describes this young woman as a lithe, graceful, open form dancing on a shore. Wearing a stylish black dress, she glides forward, her streaming hair emphasizing her motion. The exhibition features early twentieth-century drawings of women selected from the Cabinet of American Illustration Collection and the Swann Collection of Caricature and Cartoon Collection. loc.gov/exhibits/beauties/index.html

American Lumbermen , September 22, 1923 books.google.com/books?id=SEAcAQAAMAAJ&pg=RA11-PA60&a... indicates that "Socrate Barozzi, the Rumanian violinist, will make his American debut at the Town Hall, at forty-third Street, east of Broadway" in November 1923. He was to be playing a Stradivarius violin that had been bought for him in the summer of 1923 in London at William Hill & Sons by his father-in-law, Philip S. Gardner of Laurel, Miss., and former president of the Southern Pine Association. Perhaps this was taken in the Hill shop in London.

There is a book published in 1902 by the Hill family on Stradivarius, that was made available on the web on a website known as Cello Heaven (now inactive). See web.archive.org/web/20131109023907/http://www.cello.org/h... The authors are W. Henry Hill, Arthur F. Hill & Alfred E. Hill.

The current U.S. Embassy in Rumania/Romania is a modern building at 4-6, Dr. Liviu Librescu Blvd. District 1, Bucharest See Streetview from 2019

Evening star. March 16, 1924, Page 5, Image 81 chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn83045462/1924-03-16/ed-... has a piece about Bucharest by a Frank G. Carpenter. It mentions the American legation: "Leaving this scene, I drove on by palace after palace until I came to the American legation, which. I am glad to say, has one of the best houses of Bucharest. It belongs to a Rumanian millionaire, who lives in the attic, and our minister pays for it, I venture, a rental several times that allowed by the government. Uncle Sam is generous in many ways, but he is mighty mean to his diplomats. The house is a great three-story mansion, with a large and beautiful garden, containing a fountain and statues of marble. The rooms are furnished with fine old pieces, paintings and rugs, which the minister has picked up in his long diplomatic service, and the whole is a home and place for entertainment of which the United States should be proud." LoC has an album of photos by Frank Carpenter, www.loc.gov/pictures/collection/coll/item/2005675484/ but I was unable to find one of the U.S. Legation.
Around 1933-34, the U.S. Legation appears to have been in yet a different building. See digital.library.unt.edu/ark:/67531/metadc1755521/?q=bucha...
Frank G. Carpenter was a writer and world traveler. He gave his collection of photos he took and ones he collected to us in the Prints & Photographs Division.

Writers in the 1890s and early 1900s described the “New Woman” as an independent and often well-educated, young woman poised to enjoy a more visible and active role in the public arena. The Gibson Girl represented the visual ideal of this new phenomenon.

This poster advertising for a June issue of Scribner's Magazine shows the Gibson Girl's ability to enjoy strenuous physical activities. Through depictions of young women bicycling, playing tennis and golf, horseback riding, and swimming, artist Charles Dana Gibson and fellow illustrators helped promote the idea of the athletic girl as fashionable and socially acceptable.

Gibson was a major influence on my father. My dad graduated high school in '41, and after he got out of the Navy made his living for the rest of his life as what then was called a 'commercial' artist. Many of my dad's illustrations resembled Gibson's style, a style which remained popular in advertising for a great long time.
I've found sketchbooks that my dad had filled while in high school and I can see the Gibson influence.
[https://www.flickr.com/photos/johngpt] You should scan them and put them on Flickr or at least make them digital to preserve them.  If you haven't done already.
[https://www.flickr.com/photos/62155395@N02] Excellent idea. What remains of our dad's artwork is with my sister. I'm sure she'd be amenable.

For African American Music Month (June), we turn to R. Nathaniel Dett (1882-1943), a choral and piano composer inspired by African American folk songs and spirituals. In 1913, Dett began a career at the Hampton Institute and became its first Black director of music in 1926.

Dett performed at Carnegie Hall and the Boston Symphony Hall and was later a choral advisor in the United Service Organization (USO) during World War II.

A similar photo from the same roll of negatives was published in the February 6, 1959 issues of US News & World Report, but the caption just mentions that free telephone service was provided to members of Congress. 

If anyone out there can confirm these are supervisors and tell us what all they would have done, we'd love to hear.

[https://www.flickr.com/photos/jon_loc]: Notice the three in back have coiled headset cords plugged into one of the operator positions in front of them? Fun detail: notice the space on the back of each chair where a purse can be stored.

Hats off to these civil servants. They must've gotten some eccentric callers. Maybe the people in back are tallying how many callers demand to speak with the President immediately...

Bruce Bairnsfather's wife in the photo is Cecilia. Her maiden name was Cecilia Agnes Bruton, and was previously married to British golfer Michael Scott, OBE, from 1907 until they divorced in 1919. During that time she went as Cecilia Agnes Scott. Per The Biography of Captain Bruce Bairnsfather: In Search of the Better 'Ole. By Tonie Holt, Valmai Holt (books.google.ca/books?id=uiUeCgAAQBAJ) The name of the secretary may in in the book as well, but I do not have access to the full book.

Thanks [https://www.flickr.com/photos/23103743@N05] and [https://www.flickr.com/photos/195706773@N05]. We'll add her name to the catalog record. I searched some newspaper databases and they made me wonder if this photo was actually taken earlier than the date in the corner, "8/29/30". Around that time in 1930, his wife was suing another woman, Constance Collier, for "alienation of affection", by luring her husband away. It makes it doubtful he would be sailing with his wife then. I've seen other cases where Bain added a date (or in some cases more than one date) later when the photo was reused. Perhaps they wanted to distribute a photo for the store and this was the only one they had with him and his wife. The photo next to it, www.loc.gov/pictures/item/2014717175/, shows just Bairnsfather and has not date on it. I found an article which said his secretary in 1920 was named J. J. Lynch, but without knowing when this was taken or what she looks like, I'm going to hold off on adding her name to the catalog record.

The prototype Douglas World Cruiser, Army Air Service serial number AS 23-1210, McCook Field prototype number P-318. She'd later be named "Boston II." The aircraft was designed and built to US Army Air Service (USAAS) specifications for the purpose of completing the first flight around the world (hence, the ability to operate either with interchangeable fixed handing gear or floats) . Four production aircraft were built for the flight. They were named, "Seattle" (AS 23-1229), "Chicago" (AS 23-1230), "Boston" (AS 23-1231), and "New Orleans" (AS 23-1232). Both "Seattle" and "Boston" would fail to complete the journey. "Seattle" would crash in Alaska on April 30, 1924 (the story of the survival of her crew is worth learning about). "Boston" would be forced to land at sea near the Faroe Islands after her engine failed. She'd be irreparably damaged in the forced landing, and would sink while being towed by the light cruiser USS Richmond (CL-9), on August 3, 1924. After the loss of "Boston," the prototype (AS 23-1210) was pressed into service for the remainder of the flight, now named "Boston II." It would join the flight at Pictou Harbor, Nova Scotia, on September 3, 1924. Read more: en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Douglas_World_Cruiser en.wikipedia.org/wiki/First_aerial_circumnavigation
