Another description of the survival of the crew of the Seattle is at web.archive.org/web/20120622074326/http://www.alaskaairmu... This piece has a photo of the crashed plane. The Palisadian. September 12, 1924, ROTOGRAVURE SECTION, Image 9 chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn84020438/1924-09-12/ed-... also includes a picture of the crashed plane.

I believe this to be some type of seismograph. The margin of paper on the chart recorder inside cabinet and wrapped around the drum reads, "April 25, 1924." There's an unreadable, engraved plate at top center of the cabinet. The human subject seems to be applying a liquid from the Aladdin tray to the roll (chart) paper. There's a similar chart recorder in the cabinet behind and above the roll paper being handled by the human subject. This could also be measurement of some other phenomenon such as radio signal propagation or solar flares.

[https://www.flickr.com/photos/195176867@N05] I was thinking seismograph too. I thought at first it was some sort of device for transmitting photographs electronically but it looks like there is some kind of oscillating arm at the top of the drum on the left that presumably slides along the white painted guide arm. And the date . Although I wonder why they would need to treat the paper when I imagine it would be simpler  to have a ink marking device instead.

Human subject in the photo might be Frederick Emmons Terman. That would make it less likely to be seismic equipment. If this proved to be Terman, the photos are likely to have been made at Massachusetts Institute of Technology.

The description of the Georgetown photo includes, "Jesuits have contributed much to the field of seismology, which has even been termed the Jesuit Science."

Searching the Georgetown University Archives for "seismograph" I find an even more similar photo, from the same angle as the H&E photo, with one of the seismographs in a similar cabinet and the other not in a cabinet. hdl.handle.net/10822/1046745 BTW, although the description does not identify the man in this Georgetown photo, it is definitely Father Francis A. Tondorf. LoC has another H&E photo that identifies him. We recently found some old catalog cards for Harris & Ewing that had a caption for this photo. Harris & Ewing's caption for this photo is: 

"WHAT IS THE WAVE-LENGTH OF “OLD MAN STATIC”, nature’s most powerful broadcasting station? This photograph shows E.B. Judson of the Bureau of Standards and the static recorder he is using to run down the pranks of static and also to determine on what wave lengths this trouble-maker to radio reception operates."

Unit at right of frame is a teleprinter or teletype. Some nomenclatures describe this unit as a KSR or keyboard, send, and receive. The unit shown may be a Teletype Corporation Model 15. Text typed locally here can be instantly reproduced on a remote machine via telephone or radio path. In the middle is a keyboard and perforator. The operator can record a draft message on punched paper tape. When completed, the perforated tape is fed into a reader which sends the message to remote units. Pre-recorded messages, such as tornado warnings, can be stored on paper tape for rapid transmission. The left device is a printer. Printed messages appear on roll paper which can be torn off at any length. Modern ASCII devices use 7- or 8-bits to describe each character. This system uses 5-bits (BAUDOT) to describe each character. I'm not the expert. Your corrections to the above are very welcomed.

Going off of your comments I searched some newspapers from 1931 and found a similar of photo of the same people and machine at chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn83045462/1931-07-18/ed-.... For those wondering, the newspaper says this was taken at the American Telephone & Telegraph Co. offices and shows their new system for transmitting weather maps.

Ok. Yes. The maps were not sent. The article says "outline maps are inserted in the machine." The blank maps were a pre-printed form. These are impact printers that make one character at a time. They can't draw in detail. See FIVE-UNIT WEATHER CODES on the link that follows. The teletype had a weather symbols type box installed. It went to the correct location on the pre-printed map then typed the weather condition in that location.

The process and the device is generically called a telecine, a portmanteau of television and cinema. It scans the film and converts the 24 fps of film to the 30 fps used in video transmission and alters the aspect ratio. See: en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Telecine
I think Jenkins' television ran at 15 fps (with a resolution of 48x48).

This music appears to be written in mensural notation, which would place it before approximately AD 1600.  It is definitely not Handel's Dixit Dominus, but it does use the Dixit Dominus text, which is the Vulgate psalm 109 (Psalm 110 in standard numbering).  I truly have no idea why the book is so large; perhaps it was meant to be read from a distance.  I would love to learn more about that!

I remember seeing a large book like this at the chained library [www.wimborneminster.org.uk/110/chained-library.html] in Wimborne Minster [en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wimborne_Minster_(church)] and being told by the guide that it was for use by the choir, i.e., for several people at the same time.

These very large books were definitely used during choir singing during the 13th to the 16th century. Choir singing was different then from now where each choir member has its own part in his/her hand. I noticed that some of these books could be as large as 3 feet when opened. The early samples were highly decorated as can be seen here www.metmuseum.org/toah/hd/choi/hd_choi.htm Apparently not this one which looks very austere. Just the music and no more. It would be nice to locate the library as I trust it will still be somewhere around.

en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Karin_Branzell "Karin Branzell (24 September 1891 – 15 December 1974) was a Swedish operatic contralto (sometimes described as a mezzo-soprano), who had a prominent career at the Metropolitan Opera, New York, and in Europe. Her very wide range enabled her to sing both contralto roles and the occasional soprano role. She was particularly noted for her singing of the music of Richard Wagner, in roles such as Ortrud (Lohengrin), Venus (Tannhäuser), Erda (Das Rheingold and Siegfried), Brangäne (Tristan und Isolde), and Brunnhilde (Die Walküre). ... She first appeared at the Metropolitan Opera on 6 February 1924, singing Fricka in Die Walküre, and sang there every season until 1944. She returned for a farewell season in 1951, singing Erda in Rudolf Bing's first Ring cycle."

Could be the Margot Greville who was in "Madame Pompadour" in Philadelphia in October 1924 with a move to New York planned according to Billboard of November 1924 books.google.com/books?id=_JM9AQAAIAAJ&pg=PA486&l... She was also billed as Margot Greville in a British 1924 silent film called Moonbeam Magic. She was clearly an adventurous, much-married, and creative individual, and is the subject of a biography by Margot Schwass, "All the Juicy Pastures: Greville Texidor and New Zealand," published in 2020. She took the last name Texidor from one of her husbands and used "Greville Texidor" as an author in New Zealand. For background, see www.stuff.co.nz/entertainment/books/113024563/greville-te... [post by Sharon Stephenson, Jun 15 2019, that includes this photo] and Does anyone have any information about the date and identity of the sitter in this Augustus John portrait? [illuminating question and comment thread starting in April 2021] www.artuk.org/artdetective/discussions/discussions/does-a... There is also a Wikipedia page en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Greville_Texidor It is worth noting that this Wikipedia page was created recently (in March 2021) and is likely based on the biography. The summary is: "Margaret Greville Foster (1902 — 20 August 1964), best known by her pen name Greville Texidor, was an English fiction writer, notable for her work written while living in New Zealand from 1940 to 1948. After traveling the world as a performer and fighting alongside her husband for the Republicans in the Spanish Civil War, Texidor went into exile in New Zealand with her family during the early years of World War II, pushed out of England due to her husband's German background and the couple's radical politics. In New Zealand, she began writing fiction and joined Auckland's literary community. Her short stories and novellas, compiled posthumously in the collection In Fifteen Minutes You Can Say a Lot: Selected Fiction, are considered an important contribution to the existentialist period in New Zealand's literary canon."

Thanks for all this information and determining who this was despite the misspelling  [https://www.flickr.com/photos/23103743@N05] . I found an article in the March 1924 issue of "Pictures and The Picturegoer" which talks about the film Moonbeam Magic and shows her in the same outfit.

See NYT, February 29, 1924 www.nytimes.com/1924/02/29/archives/alien-bars-raised-for... "It was a happy ending that the immigration officials added yesterday to the many distressing adventures of the Baron and Baroness Michael Royce Garrett, who arrived in the steerage of the liner Olympic. The Baron had lost his money and his left leg during the Bolshevist regime in Russia; his wife saw her parents killed, and after many sufferings both fled when a death sentence hung over their heads." His wife was apparently a coloratura soprano. She performed in London in 1922. See photo at bottom left in the Evening Star. December 18, 1922, page 15 chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn83045462/1922-12-18/ed-... According to the Midland Journal., April 04, 1924, page 2 chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn89060136/1924-04-04/ed-... she was Miss Vassilieff Novossilitzeff before their marriage. But the Indianapolis Times. October 25, 1924, Home Edition, Page 5 chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn82015313/1924-10-25/ed-... calls her Vera Lavrova.

In 1926, she committed suicide in dramatic fashion. See Evening Star. August 02, 1926, Page 3, top of column3, with pictures in column 2. "The baroness leaped to her death from the 18th floor of the fashionable Everglades Hotel. The baron, clasping a piece of heavy twine, was found by police in a dense thicket north of Miami, where, he said, he was about to hang himself. A suicide pact of seven years’ standing entered into between the two after the baroness, a noted singer, had lost a $5,000,000 heritage in the upheaval following the war and trouble with bolshevik In Russia, caused the couple to plan death. - Wanted to Die Together. The baron today expressed disappointment that his youthful wife had not died with him, as she had promised." See also full page in New Britain Herald. September 10, 1926, Second Section, Image 27 chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn82014519/1926-09-10/ed-...
Thanks  [https://www.flickr.com/photos/23103743@N05], we'll put their full names. It's a very interesting story. He ended up remarrying and living until 1967.
I looked up his immigration paperwork and he lists his wife's name as Sophie.

Constance Baker Motley raises her hand in a victory sign shortly after her election as the first African American to serve in the New York State Senate. A lawyer and civil rights activist, Motley was also the first African American female federal judge.

In 1978, as a judge in the Southern District of New York, she ruled that female reporters must be allowed into Major League Baseball locker rooms.

Born enslaved to a Missouri family in 1859, Charles S. L. Baker was a self-taught engineer and later attended Franklin College after the Civil War ended.

He invented and patented a radiator that heats up with friction, after experimenting for over 20 years with metals and other materials. He was known as the "King of Clean Energy" because the friction heater could use different types of power (wind, water, or gasoline).

Welcome for Lieut. Corliss Hooven Griffis, unsuccessful kidnapper of the notorious draft dodger, Grover Cleveland Bergdoll. Evening Star. February 12, 1924, Page 11, top of col 3. chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn83045462/1924-02-12/ed-... has piece titled "Griffis is Accorded Welcome in Gotham [i.e., New York City]" "NEW YORK, February 12.—A hero’s welcome was accorded to C. Hooven Griffis, who arrived here on the American liner Albert Ballln yesterday. Griffis recently was released from a German prison, to which he was sentenced after an unsuccessful attempt to bring Grover Cleveland Bergdoll to America for trial as a draft evader. The city’s official welcoming tug, the Macom, went down the bay to meet the Ballin and take Griffis to the Battery, whence he was to have been transported to the city hall to be greeted by Acting Mayor Collins and given the freedom of the metropolis. Misunderstanding Balks Plans. Due, however, to a misunderstanding, Griffis did not get aboard the Macom. The Ballln’s ladder was hauled in before he could disembark, leaving his parents and half the welcoming delegation on the Macom and the remainder on the Ballln. The liner’s captain said he 'didn’t know there was a hero aboard or a welcoming delegation alongside.' Compelled to remain on the liner until she docked, Griffis talked about his adventures in Germany. Later he was photographed with an American flag as he stood with the statue of the Goddess of Liberty as a background."
Thanks  [https://www.flickr.com/photos/23103743@N05] for digging up the details of this story. I'm a bit of a WWI enthusiast and I don't think I'd ever heard of this. We'll update the catalog record.

Haller visited and toured the U.S. in late 1923. The NYT of October 7, 1923 timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1923/10/07/10601107... reports his arrival the day before on the French liner France. "General Joseph Haller, one of the Polish national heroes of the war, arrived yesterday on the French liner France for a four weeks' tour of the United States as the guest of the American Legion and Polish Veterans' Association. He will leave today for San Francisco to attend the Legion national convention and will return to New York on Nov. 8 for a few days before sailing for home." He was still in the U.S. in mid-December. See the New Britain Herald. December 13, 1923, page 1 chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn82014519/1923-12-13/ed-... Jednośc Polek = Unity of Polish women. December 18, 1923, page 1, under picture, chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn83035481/1923-12-18/ed-... is a letter to the community of Polish emigrés from General Haller, indicating that he is leaving the U.S. "today." NYT of December 16, 1923 timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1923/12/16/10497507... reports that he left for Europe on the Majestic and was given a big farewell.

Extract of OCR translated by Google Translate "Miss Emilja Napieralska, president of the Union of Polish Women in America, " The man at right is Wladislaw Wroblewski according to caption on another Bain photo taken at this occasion, See www.loc.gov/pictures/item/2014716809/ So he would be Władysław Wróblewski en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Władysław_Wróblewski His Polish Wikipedia entry pl.wikipedia.org/wiki/Władysław_Wróblewski says, after applying Google Translate, "From March 15, 1921 to November 9, 1922, he was an envoy of the Republic of Poland in London, and from November 10, 1922 to October 13, 1925, an envoy of the Republic of Poland in Washington."

Mme. Josef Adamowska is the former Antoinette Szumowska. Her husband Josef was a cellist. He came to the US in 1889 and played with the Boston Symphony until 1907 and then taught at the New England Conservatory until April 1930, shortly before his death. They were married in 1895. She was a pianist and studied with Paderewski. See The Adamowskis: Musicians and Patriots by Bronislas A. Jezierski [Polish American Studies Vol. 5, No. 1/2 (Jan. - Jun., 1948), pp. 14-32 (19 pages)] www.jstor.org/stable/20147140 en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Antoinette_Szumowska indicates that "she was awarded the Officer's Cross of the Order of Polonia Restituta, in 1924, a decoration presented by her former teacher Paderewski." Her NYT obituary timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1938/08/19/98181278... indicates that she had been the President of the Friends of Poland Society in Boston during WWI.

NYT of Jan 27, 1924 timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1924/01/27/10402985... indicates that Paderewski was to award the Order of Polonia Restituta to fifteen Polish-Americans in Chicago and that there had been a similar ceremony in New York the previous month.

en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Henry_Morgenthau_Sr. "Henry Morgenthau (/ˈmɔːrɡəntaʊ/; April 26, 1856 – November 25, 1946) was a German-born American lawyer and businessman, best known for his role as the ambassador to the Ottoman Empire during World War I. Morgenthau was one of the most prominent Americans who spoke about the Greek genocide and the Armenian genocide." According to the Evening Star. September 30, 1923, page 1, col 6 near top chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn83045462/1923-09-30/ed-... "GENEVA, September 29.—Henry Morgenthau. former American ambassador to Turkey, will head a special commission which was appointed tonight by the council of the League of Nations to supervise the status of 1,000,000 refugees now concentrated in Greece, and for whom a loan of about 120,000,000 will be floated by the Greek government under auspices of the league. The council has approved the entire scheme for the relief of the refugees, including their settlement on lands set apart by the Greek government, and Mr. Morgenthau will preside over what will be known as the refugees’ settlement commission, which will work independently of the Greek government. He was asked to accept the position because of his experience in relief organization." Most of the refugees are people of Greek heritage who had been expelled by the Turks during the 1923 population exchange en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Population_exchange_between_Greece_... or the genocide that preceded the exchange. en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Greek_genocide According to the Evening Star. December 31, 1923, Page 5, col 2, 1/2 way down. chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn83045462/1923-12-31/ed-... "SALONIKI, December 31.—The arrival in Saloniki of Henry Morgenthau, former United States ambassador to Turkey, as chairman of the refugee settlement commission of the league of nations, has officially opened the greatest project of re-establishing a homeless refugee population that probably ever has been undertaken. With John Campbell of Great Britain, the second member of the commission, Mr. Morgenthau made a brief survey of refugee conditions in Saloniki and adjacent territories, after which the two commissioners proceeded to Athens to confer with the government and start drafting plans for the agricultural settlements which the league has authorised in its loan of 325,000,000 to Greece. At the present time hundreds of thousands of refugees are crowded into Saloniki, Macedonia and western Thrace, dependent upon government doles and what feeding- can be given by British and American relief organizations. The immediate purpose of the commission is to establish the agriculturalists among them upon the untilled lands of Macedonia and western Thrace. This involves a scientific estimate of the nature of soils, the division of the refugees into groups such as wheat, tobacco and vine cultivators for assignment to various districts, and the providing of houses, barns, livestock, implements and feeds which will enable them to get into production."

This photo was published in a flyer from Near East Relief neareastmuseum.com/2016/06/01/athens-revisited/ For a picture of the building in which these orphans were housed, see neareastmuseum.com/2016/05/20/strangers-strange-land-near...

These are the American skaters who competed in the 1924 winter Olympics. According to the Evening Star. January 14, 1924, Page 27, chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn83045462/1924-01-14/ed-... "PARIS, January 14.—The American Olympic skating team, in charge of William Taylor, the manager, reached Paris yesterday, much fatigued from an unusually rough crossing. Charles Jewtraw, Harry Kaskey, William Steinmetz. Valentine Bialis and Richard Donovan recuperated promptly, but Joe Moore was seasick for nine days, and is badly used up. The team will leave for Chamonix this evening. Miss Beatrix Loughran, the champion figure skater, accompanied the team."

The team left for Europe on the President Monroe on January 2, 1924 according to the Evening Star. January 03, 1924, page 30, col 2, near top chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn83045462/1924-01-03/ed-... The Winter Olympics began on January 26, 1924. en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Speed_skating_at_the_1924_Winter_Ol... The Alaska Daily Empire. January 16, 1924, Page 5, col 2 has a portrait of Beatrix Loughran with the same label attached to her fur. chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn84020657/1924-01-16/ed-... So it is likely that the Bain group picture was taken at the beginning of the trip to Europe. I think it must have been on the outgoing trip, because Beatrix Loughran went on to the world figure-skating championships (Feb 16-17, 1924). See en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1924_World_Figure_Skating_Champions... Meanwhile, according to the Omaha Morning Bee. February 14, 1924, CITY EDITION, Page 12, col 3, near bottom chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn84024326/1924-02-14/ed-... the male speed-skaters were expected to compete in the upcoming national amateur speed-skating championships at Saranac, N.Y. (on Lake Placid). For a report of the event, see Evening Star. February 24, 1924, Page 2, Image 62, column 3, top chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn83045462/1924-02-24/ed-...

Delia Reinhardt en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Delia_Reinhardt_(soprano) with a player piano. en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Player_piano "A player piano (also known as a pianola) is a self-playing piano, containing a pneumatic or electro-mechanical mechanism that operates the piano action via programmed music recorded on perforated paper, or in rare instances, metallic rolls, with more modern implementations using MIDI. The rise of the player piano grew with the rise of the mass-produced piano for the home in the late 19th and early 20th century. Sales peaked in 1924, then declined as the improvement in phonograph recordings due to electrical recording methods developed in the mid-1920s." This is a Knabe player piano. See www.gentilepiano.com/player.html for some pictures of one before and after restoration.

The date written on the negative is 4/12/24. This will have been taken at the international chess championship that took place in New York in the Alamac hotel in March-April 1924. See, for instance, www.chess.com/blog/SamCopeland/the-top-10-chess-games-of-... which has a group photo of the players. The championship was a double round robin with 11 players and lasted from March 15 to April 12. Why does violinist Fritz Kreisler have a pierrot doll in this picture? Could it be because, in early 1924, he arranged and recorded Tanzlied des Pierrot (Pierrot's Dance Song) from the opera "Die Tote Stadt" (The Dead City) by E.W. Korngold? To hear it: archive.org/details/78_pierrots-dance-song_fritz-kreisler... or www.youtube.com/watch?v=zW2AA6S5bpg According to www.korngold-society.org/ClassCDs.html the recording was on March 28, 1924. For the opera: en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Die_tote_Stadt Aside: LoC has Kreisler's transcription of the song in its collections memory.loc.gov/service/music/eadxmlmusic/eadpdfmusic/uplo...

The 90th birthday of Roger Nash Baldwin was on January 21, 1974. According to the New York Times of Jan 20, 1974, the party was held before the actual birthday. www.nytimes.com/1974/01/20/archives/baldwin-founder-of-ac... Describes "Last night's reception for 60 admirers at Mr Baldwin's town house on West 11th St." Names mentioned include: Osmond K. Fraenkel Morris Ernst Mrs. Trude Lash Russell Blauvelt Edwin McAmis James Tripp His sons, Roger Jr and Carl [actually stepsons, according to his NYT obituary at www.nytimes.com/1981/08/27/obituaries/roger-baldwin-97-is... ] His daughter, Helen, Mrs Piero Mannoni Some of these may be in the photo.

Notice that at least one of the TVs behind him seems to be showing a soap opera or maybe an old movie. 

It would've been someone's job to monitor what everyone else was reporting but the 24-hour news environment was just starting - CNN was less than 2 years old and had no direct competitors yet.

I see a Western Electric 30-button Call Director (telephone) between the camera and the paper held by Mr. Brokaw.

The roll paper in his hand is probably from a Teletype Corporation Model 33 or Model 28. I'm unsure of the details but newsrooms paid subscriptions to wire services like United Press International or Reuters for vetted news feeds. This news arrived on a Teletype. These machines used roll paper so the story could be ripped off at ten lines of text or 2 feet of text.

Although Nixon spent election night at the Waldorf-Astoria, which had been his campaign headquarters, reading the NYT suggests that the closeness of the election meant that there was no public event on election night (Nov 5). timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1968/11/07/76903151... indicates that he did not appear in the ballroom until 11:35am the next day (Nov 6). See the front page of the NYT on November 7 at timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1968/11/07/76903151... The NYT of November 6 timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1968/11/06/91291961... indicates that he did not appear in the ballroom the previous night.

One has to assume that thanking some campaign staff might have been on the agenda when he did finally appear. The only female campaign staff that I have found so far are: * Annelise Anderson who participated in a 2018 event at the National Archives entitled, "Nixon Campaign Aides Revisit RN’s 1968 Election Victory." See www.nixonfoundation.org/2018/09/nixon-campaign-aides-revi... About 12:50 into the recording is a picture of Annelise from 1968. * Rose Mary Woods who was his secretary for many years. There are two photos at www.findagrave.com/memorial/10365547/rose-mary-woods

Costumes and sets for all three French operas on the program were by David Hockney. In Boston's 1,100-acre Emerald Necklace parks, you will still find Jamaica Pond.

While skaters opt for other rinks today, Jamaica Pond used to be a popular place for locals to lace up their skates and to hold an annual ice carnival.

Special delivery: the first women mail carriers.

Despite women serving as mail carriers in rural areas, they were not given the jobs in urban cities until World War I. In 1917, Permelia S. Campbell and Nellie M. McGrath became the Post Office Department's first letter carriers in a U.S. city. The two delivered mail around Union Station in Washington, D.C.

Maybe taken during the Great Inflation of the early 1920's in Germany.
en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hyperinflation_in_the_Weimar_Republic Since there have not been any postings in a month, are we still in 1923 or are we in 1924.
The date written on the negative (at bottom left) is 10/27/23. So the photo was taken no later than October 27, 1923. See also alphahistory.com/weimarrepublic/1923-hyperinflation/

The banknotes on the right are Thousand Mark notes introduced September 15, 1923: www.apcpapercollect.com/images/1germP076b1000mark.jpg By late October, when this image was taken, 1000 Marks couldn't even buy you a cup of coffee. On Oct. 25, 1923, 1 U.S. $ was worth 1,000,000,000,000 Mark (1 trillion Marks). These banknotes are stacked in the basement of the bank because they are literally not worth the paper on which they are printed. www.pbs.org/wgbh/commandingheights/shared/minitext/ess_ge...

Here's another suggestion, the conductor for the new production of Aida, Roberto Moranzoni
Conductor Roberto Moranzoni looks very different than our mystery man and doesn't wear glasses. I've looked at the other male members of the "Aida" cast as well and don't think it's any of them.

I looked through lots of newspapers databases this morning trying to confirm or deny if our man is Roberto Moranzoni. Unfortunately newspapers and magazines prefer to show the performers rather than the conductor. 

On first look, I didn't think it was him, but after seeing a few photos, I'm now unsure. I did find some photos of Moranzoni wearing glasses, and the same round glasses as in our photo. Comparing this photo to the one  [https://www.flickr.com/photos/23103743@N05] posted, I notice they have very similar chins, and both have that slight dimple in their cheeks. 

I can't post it here because I found it in a subscription database, but there was a photo published in the November 2nd, 1930 Chicago Tribune, where his face is turned at a similar angle. He's not smiling in this photo, and it's rather grainy because it's a scan from microfilm of a newspaper image, but he looks a lot more similar than in some of the other images I came across. 

At this point I'm open to it being Moranzoni, but I'm not convinced enough to add it to the catalog record. I'll be back on-site next week and I'll try searching a few additional places there. I welcome any addition photos people can find.

Conductor Roberto Moranzoni, as I now see, also has the exact same dimple in his chin as the mystery man here. Together with the information that there are photos of him wearing glasses, as on this image [www.centrostudibaresi.it/roberto-moranzoni-di-alfredo-gio...], I now think swanq is right after all. On another picture I found, by the way, Moranzani is wearing a pince-nez: commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:Roberto_Moranzoni,_by_Her...

The Library's Music Division had a little booklet on Moranzoni which included some more photos. I nearly convinced it is him at this point. I will ask our cataloger to say it is probably Roberto Moranzoni.

The man at left could be Wolfram Humperdinck, the only son of Engelbert Humperdinck, the German composer, well known for his Hansel and Gretel operetta. See www.kn-online.de/Nachrichten/Kultur/Theater-Kiel-Dokument... and sites.google.com/a/enoces.host/allanthgfhilton/zwei-sohne...

Schimmer could be a typo for Schirmer, from the music publishing business. See en.wikipedia.org/wiki/G._Schirmer,_Inc.. Looking at www.encyclopedia.com/arts/dictionaries-thesauruses-pictur... suggests that one possibility is that this is Gustav(e) Schirmer III. But there are other Schirmers involved in the music industry.

De Bekker's Music & Musicians: An Encyclopaedic Dictionary of Terms and Biographies, with Stories of the Operas, revised to 1924-25. books.google.com/books?id=kHc6AAAAIAAJ&pg=PA285&l... says, that Engelbert Humperdinck's "son Wolfram conducted the New York production of 'The Miracle,' 1924." Musical Courier of Nov 29, 1923 www.google.com/books/edition/Musical_Courier_and_Review_o... reports, "All of New York is very much interested in Morris Gest's production of The Miracle which Max Reinhardt came to America to make a special presentation of. Wolfram Humperdinck, son of the famous composer who has written the music for The Miracle, arrived in this country last week. Mr Humperdinck is in this country representing the Humperdinck estate as Engelbert Humperdinck the composer specified in his will that there should be no extraneous performances of The Miracle without his son's assistance. With Mr Reinhardt came Friederick Schirmer, a composer and a winner of the Rome prize for composition. With them was also Fritz Helf who will be one of the assistant stage managers of the production and also take part. The Miracle promises to be the most stupendous pantomime ever offered in this country." So this photo must be of Wolfram Humperdinck and Friederick Schirmer. The spelling of Schirmer's first name varies, but WorldCat has his name as Schirmer, Friedrich 1881-1926. See worldcat.org/identities/lccn-n96011589/ which lists among other works by and about Friedrich Schirmer: Sayler, Oliver M., ed. F. Ray Comstock and Morris Gest Present for the First Time in America the Stupendous, Spectacular Pantomime, the Miracle: Staged by Max Reinhardt; Book by Karl Vollmoeller; Score by Engelbert Humperdinck, Revised and Extended by Friedrich Schirmer; Production Designed by Norman-Bel Geddes; Built by P. J. Carey & Co. Entire Production under the Personal Supervision of Morris Gest: Souvenir. New York: Sackett & Wilhelms, 1926.

As noted, renown aviator and Army Air Service test pilot John A. Macready. Not only was Macready distinguished as an aviator and test pilot, he's also considered by many to be the father of Aviator-style sunglasses. See: www.nytimes.com/2012/08/05/magazine/who-made-those-aviato...
Who Made Those Aviator Sunglasses? By Pagan Kennedy New York Times Magazine (Page 20) - Aug. 5, 2012 Early in the 20th century, as test pilots began flying higher than Mount Everest, they had to defend themselves against temperatures as low as minus-80 degrees Fahrenheit. To survive the frigid blast, aviators wore leather hoods, and they insulated their eyes with fur-lined goggles. To lift those goggles for even an instant was to risk death. In 1920, when Shorty Schroeder dared to take a biplane above 33,000 feet, his goggles fogged and he had no choice but to pull them off. Moments later, his vision blurred, and his eyes were soon frozen over. Schroeder managed to land the plane that day, and his friend John Macready helped pull him out of the cockpit. A month later, still haunted by the memory of his friend’s swollen eyelids, Macready climbed into the same plane to beat Schroeder’s altitude record. Like Schroeder, Macready depended on goggles that had been designed to seal his eyes from the cold and protect his sight. But the early goggles were not dark enough, and “the bright sunlight in the upper atmosphere hurt his eyes,” said his daughter, Sally Macready Wallace. And so Macready began working with Bausch & Lomb to design goggles especially suited to protect against the dazzle in the stratosphere. “My dad gave Bausch & Lomb the original shape, tint and fit” of aviator lenses, Wallace said. By the late 1930s, advertisements for Bausch & Lomb’s Ray Ban sunglasses promised “real scientific glare protection” for fishermen and golfers. Not yet called aviators, the glasses nonetheless captured the essence of aviator goggles, with their teardrop shape and frames as delicate as a biplane’s struts. Sold as sporting equipment, they cost several dollars at a time when sunglasses could be had for 25 cents. During World War II, aviators became standard gear for military men, including Gen. Douglas MacArthur. . .

I agree. I understand the fear people had after Pearl Harbor but most of these people were American Citizens and should have been treated the same as the German Americans. Some German Americans were locked up but most of those were of questionable character or were loyal to Germany. 

Both my wife and I had some German ancestors in this country at that time. They were all loyal Americans who contributed to the war effort and not one of them was ever locked up or even questioned about their loyalty to this nation.

[https://www.flickr.com/photos/target_man_2000] There  had been an active and by-no-means-secret effort by the Nazis before the war to recruit German-Americans to return, and in some cases it succeeded. The book "Small Wonder", written in the '60s about the VW Beetle phenomenon, documents the fact that the city that would become Wolfsburg did not appear on the Allies' ground maps having been built from scratch starting in 1938, and as the war was ending with the Nazi government all but collapsed, the city's Catholic priest  was sent to the Americans in Braunschweig to get them to occupy the town before the Russians did. 
One of the points he made was that there were  a dozen or so American children there, the US-born kids of such returnees. That was enough to get them into  Wolfsburg before the Soviets even knew what was there, and strikes me as a far  cry from the raw race hatred that many had for the Japanese.

Interned persons were housed in horse stables at Santa Anita race track. Internees included both US Citizens of japanese ancestry and japanese nationals. ==== [Witnesses were called to appear before the Tolan Committee to relate the problems with internment.] To the Japanese in Japan, Pastor [W.P.] Reagor suggested to the committee, it would appear that the United States was doing to the people here what Germany was doing to the Jews. Source: Fox, Stephen, “In Defense of Italian Americans,” The Unknown Internment: An Oral History of the Relocation of Italian Americans during World War II, (Boston: Twayne Publishers, 1990) pp.118. We as colored soldiers in Fort Benning, Georgia, in 1941 and ’42, could not go into the main Post Exchange or the main theater in Fort Benning, Georgia. When we passed the main Post Exchange and looked in we could see the German and Italian prisoners of war sitting down at the same table with white soldiers, drinking Cokes and smoking and having a good time. So it is understandable how colored soldiers would have an inferiority complex. [We thought] there must be something wrong with us. We are in uniform… but we are not good enough to sit at the table with prisoners of war. — Walter Morris Source: “Stories from the Veterans History Project Collection: Walter Morris,” Folklife Center News, Spring 2004, Volume XXVI, Number II, pp.12.

The man sitting on the tractor is Maurice Tsutomu Shinmoto.  He came to America from Hiroshima, Japan to visit relatives in Stockton, CA.  While here in the USA he worked on the farm being managed by his mother's cousin, Harry Futamachi, in Terminus, CA.  Here he is sitting on a Holt tractor that he drove in the fields.  Holt tractors were built in nearby Stockton, CA.  While his intent was to return to Japan, WW2 started and he was sent to the internment camp in Rohwer, AK and then later to Tule Lake, CA.  After spending three years in incarceration he returned to Japan.

[https://www.flickr.com/photos/fonziandfritz] All the signage you see, the writing in the window, the boards for the shops, all done by hand. In the 1941 movie, The Maltese Falcon, when Sam Spade's partner, Archer, is killed, the signage for the office doors and the next day, in script terms, a guy shows up with his brush and guide-stick. In other words, if you had the money to pay for it, a sign like this could be knocked out in a few hours, and put up in 30-40 minutes, so yes, it's entirely possible. If that particular sign-painting company was owned by a Japanese-American, I would bet that they would be even more likely to put a rush on the order. As for anti-Asian sentiment, it was endemic to the culture of the time, so it's unlikely there was any previous specific precipitating incident, but it's always possible that there may have been.

As a result of the bombing of Pearl Harbor, the Japanese of Mountain View [California] were intimidated because of Moffett Field’s location, (a military installation). One evening our house was shot into and the bullet missed my father’s friend by inches. Many restrictions on our movements began to inconvenience us. We were ordered to leave Mountain View on May 22, 1942. — Tak Hori Source: “Tak Hori,” Bittersweet: Memories of Old Mountain View — an Oral History, (Mountain View, Calif.: City of Mountain View Public Library, 1980) Volume 1, pp.31.

This note is intended to help any future researcher trying to geo-locate the home site. Thank you for the high resolution link. Location clues include: - Mail address: Route 1 Box 353 - This address has "front feeds": the utility poles are along the street. - The angle of service drop wires suggests poles are along the same side of the street as the home shown. - The house has single-phase utility power. - The house has a telephone line, probably a party line. - There is a hose bib to the viewer's right of the dog. The house may have running water. Guess: unless somebody can nail down the postal address, I can only guess it's in the area of present-day Fairchild Drive, Whisman Road, or along Charleston Road (the present-day Googleplex). Transportation was weighted toward what is now the northern side of town. The first municipal water system elements I know of were in northeast present-day Mountain View.

What I find more interesting is the caption, which essentially is a pack of lies. Did farmers in rural areas of, say Georgia, close to Army bases, get "relocated"? What this picture shows is the government, fueled by racist paranoia, uprooting and stealing a life from people who had spent decades creating it, and who were not repaid for the theft until the 1980s, when the young people in the photo would have been close to retirement age.

[https://www.flickr.com/photos/theonemacduff]: my incomplete understanding is that Executive Order 9066 allowed the Secretary of War to draw a line on the map anywhere. People on the exclusion side of the line were forced to "relocate" to "internment" (prison) camps. So far as I know, this only included the west coast of the United States. In my opinion, there was no due process for the interned people who were US citizens. There was not even a requirement for probable cause. A line on the map drawn by some official: that's it. There were other camps run by the Department of Justice and not based on exclusion areas. They hauled in prisoners from anywhere in the US. In hindsight, it seems like all of this was unfounded. This was a low point in the history of a country that claims to value civil rights. At what cost to the democratic spirit, this obsession with national security? …None of the anxiety widely reported in the popular and academic presses and gobbled up by gullible government officials and the citizenry was justified by any reality. The imagined legions of domestic enemies of democracy did not exist. Source: Fox, Stephen, “Preface,” The Unknown Internment: An Oral History of the Relocation of Italian Americans during World War II, (Boston: Twayne Publishers, 1990) pp.xiv-xv. [During World War I] ...the whole country was beset by semiofficial spies calling themselves 'volunteer aides' to the Department of Justice. Many of these persons were discredited politicians endeavoring as ‘patrioteers’ to recover lost ground and join the more fortunate group of ‘profiteers." They tampered with the mails, wrote decoy letters, invaded private offices and homes without warrant to insert Dictaphones, and in general violated the rights of private citizens without fear of restraint or punishment. Apparently they were mentally unable or unwilling to distinguish between opposition to our entrance into the war and working for defeat when once embarked on it. ...hysterical intolerance is a natural product of war. Source: Jordan, David Starr, Days of a Man: Being Memories of a Naturalist, Teacher, and a Minor Prophet of Democracy, (Yonkers-on-Hudson, New York: World Book Company,1922) Volume 2, pp.750-751.

My mother, Rose Nieda, nee Serizawa, was interned at Tule Lake, but recalls the hospital there.  It was a barracks, staffed by unlicensed, fellow evacuees just out of medical school, with licensed Caucasians acting only as administrators.  She remembers going there for a toothache, and they extracted several molars, leaving gaps in her mouth until she was able to repair the damage after the war.  It was chaos.
Thank you [https://www.flickr.com/photos/196286361@N02] for sharing your mother's experience in the camp. It helps us understand what life was like in there.

en.wikipedia.org/wiki/SS_United_States "SS United States is a retired ocean liner built in 1950–51 for the United States Lines at a cost of US$79.4 million. The ship is the largest ocean liner constructed entirely in the United States and the fastest ocean liner to cross the Atlantic in either direction, retaining the Blue Riband for the highest average speed since her maiden voyage in 1952. She was designed by American naval architect William Francis Gibbs and could be converted into a troopship if required by the Navy in time of war. United States maintained an uninterrupted schedule of transatlantic passenger service until 1969 and was never used as a troopship." Photos of the ship during construction, launch, and maiden voyage can be seen at www.nytimes.com/slideshow/2015/10/06/business/ss-united-s... It's not obvious why this photo was filed by Bain among photos from September 1923, except possibly because it was seen as relevant to the September 13 coup, which resulted in the installation of a military government. See, e.g., Evening star. September 16, 1923, Page 3, Image 43 chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn83045462/1923-09-16/ed-... "A little coup has been “pulled off” in Spain; swift, bloodless, bizarre. The thaumaturge, so to speak, is pro De Rivera, a high grandee and captain general or the military area of Catalonia, which comprises the provinces of Barcelona, Gerona, Leruia and Tarragona. On the night of September 12-13 the captain general declared a “state of siege” in Catalonia. The same time he issued a pronunciamento inviting the Spanish military outside Catalonia to join his movement, the main objects of which are “to put an end to wastefulness in government, to insure liberty to labor, to establish rapidly and without passion the responsibilities for the Morocco disasters, and completely to change the conduct of the Rif campaign.”

The chair is somewhat like www.ebay.co.uk/itm/193890054755 listed as Antique Victorian Barley Twist Heavily Carved Jacobean Style Oak Chair. According to www.baltimoresun.com/news/bs-xpm-1997-02-16-1997047209-st... "One popular furniture technique is a type of wood turning that first appeared in England and France in the 1600s. Furniture with spiral-turned legs or trim was known as "barley twist" or "barley sugar," probably because it resembled sticks of barley sugar used at the time. The twist was difficult to make of oak because that wood is brittle. It often was made of walnut or beech. At first it was cut by hand, then after 1660 with the help of a lathe. The twisted leg went out of style in the second half of the 18th century, when curved legs came into fashion. The 19th-century chair or table started with a straight leg, but by the 1850s some designers again used the twist."

Can't find any addresses in Menton for him though.

However, no sooner had I posted that than I found this: www.delcampe.net/fr/collections/cartes-postales/france/me... Note the rounded doorway and the large balconied building on the left, adjacent to the Tramu boutique, and then consider the view around the Place Saint Roch, up the Avenue Felix Faure in Menton: goo.gl/maps/w348nqw8xxR43p4f8 The shop on the corner is even still a perfumery! It's hard to see exactly the right angle up the road to the left of the perfume shop (Rue Partouneaux), but if you move around in streetview you can see the matching buildings.

[https://www.flickr.com/photos/fraserpettigrew] : great work! As an aside, I found at www.thegazette.co.uk/London/issue/33008/page/46/data.pdf that Tramu was listed as entitled to style himself as "By Appointment to the late Queen Victoria" in 1925.

Good detective work  [https://www.flickr.com/photos/fraserpettigrew]. I believe that is the same building (if you're looking for more old photos of Menton, there is a Facebook page entitled "Menton du passé au présent"). 

I wonder what the festival is. Their Fête du Citron didn't start until 1875.

[https://www.flickr.com/photos/jon_loc] The Lemon Festival site itself seems a little confusing, starting off by saying it began in 1895, then talking about Queen Victoria visiting in 1882 and then revealing that the lemon bit wasn't fixed until 1934! I think it's the initiation date that's wrong and Wikipedia (obviously based on this text) has it right at 1875. www.fete-du-citron.com/Lemon-festival-history.html?lang=en It does say, however, that "The festival of Menton was then [1882] very similar to its cousin in Nice: a parade of “big heads”, confetti-throwing, flower processions…" Could that be a 'big head' in the foreground, bottom left? Also, is the dating of your stereograph accurate? It's hard to tell for sure, but what I can see of normal fashions on some of the people in the street and the couple of men in the window suggests that it could be much nearer the end of the century than pre-1875.

[https://www.flickr.com/photos/fraserpettigrew] Your suggestion of a later date is likely correct. We were able to find a similar card from what appears to be the same festival, with the same couple in the second floor window with an umbrella, in an undigitized grouping of cards from festivals in Menton: www.loc.gov/pictures/item/2004676371/. The card has a copyright submission date of 1898 and is on a Littleton View Co. Underwood & Underwood mount. Littleton View Co. appears to have been active from 1883. The negative is likely from the 1890s, given the copyright date, but could also be from a few years earlier. 1864 is definitely too early, so we'll update the record to reflect the later range.

This seems likely to be the Westphalia (III), launched by HAPAG (HAMBURG-AMERIKANISCHE PACKETFAHRT ACTIEN GESELLSCHAFT) in January 1923, built at Howaldtswerke, Kiel. They operated only for a short time on the North Atlantic and were transferred to the La Plata route." A Bain photo of the same ship not yet uploaded to Flickr by LoC is at loc.gov/pictures/resource/ggbain.38961/ The ship clearly combined passenger service and bulk cargo.

en.wikipedia.org/wiki/USS_Shenandoah_(ZR-1) "USS Shenandoah was the first of four United States Navy rigid airships. It was constructed during 1922–1923 at Lakehurst Naval Air Station, and first flew in September 1923. It developed the U.S. Navy's experience with rigid airships and made the first crossing of North America by airship. On the 57th flight, Shenandoah was destroyed in a squall line over Ohio in September 1925."

Leviathan docks Monday morning WJZ, the Radio Corporation of America station in New York, will broadcast one of the greatest programs of dance music ever played. The occasion is the crowning of Paul Whiteman, the king of jazz—the place Is pier 84, North River—and the collection includes such famous orchestras as the S. S. Leviathan Vaudeville Unit, the James boys, now playing in “Little Jessie James"; Chester Frost's Bostonian Orchestra. Ben Slevin’s Orchestra and Joe Raymond and his orchestra and a special submarine band composed of members of the United Orchestras. Paul Whlteman, the world's greatest syncopator, is returning in triumph to his native heath, and his fellow musicians have a gold crown to place upon his head as he steps ashore. From the moment the Leviathan steams within earshot of the pier a never-ceasing tribute of the highest type of modern dance music will fill the air; bands in airplanes will circle over the Leviathan as she steams up the harbor, musicians in diving suits, submerged to their necks In the water of the North river, will spread jazz across the water, and five of the greatest dance orchestras in the country will be on the pier giving a continuous concert of Whiteman’s favorite dance arrangements. WJZ will have Its microphone right there in the midst of it all, carrying the entire musical orgy to the homes of the people all over the country."

en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Louise_DeKoven_Bowen "Louise DeKoven Bowen (also Louise deKoven Bowen; February 26, 1859 – November 9, 1953) was an American philanthropist, civic leader, social reformer, and suffragist. She was born to a wealthy family and raised with a strong sense of noblesse oblige. She made substantial financial donations to numerous organizations, raised funds from her association with Chicago's elite families, and while not trained as a social worker, she served in the field as a competent and respected policy maker and administrator. She worked with the settlement movement at Hull House, court reform for youth via the Juvenile Protective Association, and numerous women's clubs and women's suffrage organizations. A primary passion of hers was the reform of dance halls in Chicago. At the end of her 94 years, she had provided care to the impoverished and disenfranchised through her extensive public service and activism, especially attending to "the welfare and betterment of women, children, and their families." Widow of Joseph Tilton Bowen, Sr. www.findagrave.com/memorial/112064247/joseph-tilton-bowen

Still a hotel, now a Marriott. 2 New Montgomery Street, San Francisco, California 94105 See www.marriott.com/hotels/hotel-photos/sfolc-palace-hotel-a... August 2021 Streetview en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Palace_Hotel,_San_Francisco "The Palace Hotel is a landmark historic hotel in San Francisco, California, located at the southwest corner of Market and New Montgomery streets. The hotel is also referred to as the "new" Palace Hotel to distinguish it from the original 1875 Palace Hotel, which had been demolished after being gutted by the fire caused by the 1906 San Francisco earthquake. The present structure opened on December 19, 1909, on the same site as its predecessor."

The hotel was in the news in July/August 1923, because President Harding was there when he was ill. See similar photo in the Evening Star. According to en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Warren_G._Harding Harding died on August 2nd after a heart attack.

See theatreheritage.org.au/on-stage-magazine/general-articles... about two contemporaneous performers named Edna Thomas. If the author is correct, this could be the second one discussed in the article. 'She was born Edna Alice Gery on 13 March 1888, in New Orleans, Louisiana—hence her billing as ‘The Lady from Louisiana’. She married Albert George Thomas in New Orleans on 30 October 1907. A mezzo-soprano, this Edna developed a large repertoire of ‘creole negro songs’ and ‘spirituals’. As she explained: ‘It was from my black mammy, Ninna, who reared me, that I first learned the negro spirituals. “Sperrituals” she calls them. She has been in our family so long that she insists that her name is Dare, same as my grandmother's, “Forginny Davis Dare is my name,” she says. From London last year I sent her a letter addressed “Miss Virginia Davis Dare, alias Ninna”, and she was mighty offended. “Oh, Mis’ Ella,” she said to my mother, “that alias is no good. Only criminals have dem aliases.”’ Successful forays to Great Britain in 1923 and 1924 culminated in a reported 12-week season at the London Coliseum. This was followed by her first Australian visit.' So this could be sailing to or from Great Britain in 1923.

This is a picture of the Czech conductor Josef Stránský (1872-1936). He was the successor of Gustav Mahler as conductor of the New York Philharmonic, a post he held from 1911 till 1923. As he took the post after the world famous Mahler he had a difficult time at New York. It is astonishing today what leading 'critics' dared to write about him. But he held the post for 12 years. en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Yvette_Rugel

She was an American singer and vaudeville performer, sometimes billed as the "Miniature Prima Donna". The Evening Star. September 19, 1923, Page 12, column 3, near top chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn83045462/1923-09-19/ed-... indicates that she was just back from Europe. The Encyclopedia of Vaudeville by Anthony Slide books.google.com/books?id=Hu3nNSmRjZ0C&pg=PA443&l... describes her as a pretentious semi-operatic singer. The Alaska Daily Empire. April 24, 1925, Page 3, top center with photo and graphic chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn84020657/1925-04-24/ed-... has headline, "American Prima Donna is Honored by French" and states that she never had a singing lesson. The Evening Star. February 22, 1931, Image 43 chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn83045462/1931-02-22/ed-... has a piece under the headline "Golden-Voiced Personality”: "The old query, which weighs the most, a pound of gold or a pound of feathers, seems applicable to Yvette Rugel, one of the artists featured in this week's Capitol Theater, New York, stage revue, 'Krinoline Kapers,' at Loew's Palace. Here is a miniature prima donna, a delightful young woman with a voice out of proportion to her size, a singer whose possessions are described as a virtual treasure trove, in a setting measured by pennyweight. Miss Rugel’s voice has been called “molten gold, a flood of delightful tones, made expressive by an unusual understanding and intelligent knowledge of values which actually plays on the heartstrings. Miss Rugel also has the ability and an outstanding personality." See also travsd.wordpress.com/2013/10/15/stars-of-vaudeville-832-y...

Baron Emile de Cartier de Marchienne (1871-1946) See www.npg.org.uk/collections/search/person/mp50554/baron-em... en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Emile_de_Cartier_de_Marchienne "Baron Emile-Ernest de Cartier de Marchienne (born 30 November 1871 in Schaerbeek, Belgium, died 10 May 1946 in London, United Kingdom) was a Belgian diplomat. Emile de Cartier de Marchienne was Belgian Minister in the United States, China, the United Kingdom, Cuba, Haiti, and the Dominican Republic." From 1917 to 1927 he was Envoy Extraordinary and Minister Plenipotentiary in the USA.

His wife is the former Marie Dow. See the New-York Tribune. March 21, 1920, Page 7, Image 85, column 7 chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn83030214/1920-03-21/ed-... "Baron Emile de Cartier de Marchienne is the first Belgian Ambassador to this country, the post having been raised from a legation to an embassy shortly before his appointment in 1919. He married in Paris July 16, 1919, Mrs. Hamilton Wilkes Cary, of New York. Baroness de Cartier de Marchienne was Miss Marie B. Dow, of Boston. She has now made her third marital adventure. Her first husband was Elihu B. Frost, president of the Submarine Boat Corporation, from whom she was separated in 1909 and divorced in December of that year at Reno. January 1, 1910, she was married to Hamilton Wilkes Cary, of New York, well known socially and on the turf. He died February 15, 1917, at Palm Beach, and his widow went abroad the following winter to do relief work in France and Belgium. She first met Baron de Cartier de Marchienne during the peace conference in Paris."

The New York Times July 12, 1923 timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1923/07/12/10510703... lists notable passengers on several liners that sailed for Europe. Baron de Cartier, the Belgian Ambassador to the United States and his wife sailed on the Belgenland.

en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gilbert_Hitchcock "Gilbert Monell Hitchcock (September 18, 1859 – February 3, 1934) was an American congressman and U.S. Senator from Nebraska, and the founder of the Omaha World-Herald newspaper." The daughter with Hitchcock may be: * Margaret Hitchcock Doorly (1884–1964) -- www.findagrave.com/memorial/6678016/margaret-doorly or * Ruth Hitchcock Stewart (1891-1963) -- www.findagrave.com/memorial/72072693/ruth-stewart See also nebraskahistory.pastperfectonline.com/byperson?keyword=Hi...

According to the Tomahawk. July 26, 1923, page 2, column 4, near top. chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn89064695/1923-07-26/ed-... "Gilbert M. Hitchcock, former Nebraska senator, who led the democratic fight for ratification by the senate of the treaty of Versailles, sailed for Europe with Mrs. Hitchcock and their daughter on the Belgenland."

The New York Times July 12, 1923 timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1923/07/12/10510703... lists notable passengers on several liners that sailed for Europe and indicates that the Hitchcocks sailed with their daughter **Ruth** on the Belgenland.

[https://www.flickr.com/photos/23103743@N05] Thanks for identifying the potential daughter. Do you think this image may actually be of Hitchcock's wife, Ruth? The image looks a lot like the one on the Hitchcock Foundation website (www.hitchcockfoundation.org/history).

[https://www.flickr.com/photos/143711250@N06] -- The photo at www.hitchcockfoundation.org/history is of Hitchcock's second wife. They weren't married until 1927. Meanwhile, I find www.loc.gov/pictures/item/2016827233/ of a Ruth Hitchcock in 1919, under NPCC group caption "Society on horseback and in the parks." Could that be the same woman as the one in this Bain picture?

[https://www.flickr.com/photos/23103743@N05] I was comparing that NPCC image as well against this one to see if it was Ruth. I think you're right ruling out the wife and firming this image up as Ruth. Thanks for the extra effort!
